DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIA'S PARTICIPATION IN INTERNATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANISATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the Parliament of the Government's response to the report from the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on its inquiry into Australia's participation in international environmental organisations. The report was tabled in this House in October 1982. Although preparations were in train to present this statement to the House during the last sittings, this was not possible due to the shortness of the sittings and pressure of other business.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committee adopted the approach of being informative as well as being investigatory in preparing this report, by providing detailed descriptions of the role, structure and history of the more significant organisations. The Committee gave particular attention to Australia's involvement in three bodies: The United Nations Environment Program, UNEP; the Environment Committee of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, OECD; and the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources, IUCN. Other international bodies considered by the Committee were the World Wildlife Fund, the International Whaling Commission, the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission, the International Waterfowl Research Bureau and various United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation programs. The report made 13 recommendations. Before I describe the Government's response to the recommendations I will make some observations on the benefits to Australia of these organisations.

There are several reasons for Australia's participation in international environmental organisations. First, many of the issues considered by these organisations are inherently international because they are global in nature and cannot be resolved solely at the national level. The problems of atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, destruction of the ozone layer, contamination of the oceans, control of hazardous chemicals and protection of endangered wildlife are clear examples. Secondly, scientific knowledge necessary to solve many environmental problems is still scarce and the sharing of information and experience between countries is essential. Thirdly, consultation between nations is important to help avoid the possibility of differing national environmental policies leading to international trade distortions and affecting the competitive positions of industries in various countries. Fourthly, the close connections between the environment and economic, social and political considerations are increasingly recognised as important both within countries and between them. Finally, countries can benefit from each other's experience in a great many aspects of environmental monitoring, planning and management. Such benefits are particularly relevant to Australia because many environmental problems are acute in other countries well before they become significant in Australia.

The last two decades have seen greatly increased international activity and co-operation in relation to environmental protection and conservation, and a growing recognition of the need to reconcile economic and environmental demands through policies directed towards sustainable development. To a large extent, international organisations, particularly UNEP, IUCN and the OECD, have been responsible for this progress in international understanding of environmental problems, and for providing the stimulus for reducing these problems. Other international organisations which have played important specific roles include the World Wildlife Fund, the International Whaling Commission, the International Waterfowl Research Bureau and the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation-UNESCO-through the man and the biosphere program and the Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission.

The scope for Australia's participation in international environmental organisations is necessarily constrained by economic factors and geographical isolation. Travel costs are significant and must be carefully considered in relation to the benefits expected from attendance at particular overseas meetings. However, many of our environmental concerns are similar to those overseas-for instance, pollution control, wildlife and park management, arid land management, deforestation, waste management and recycling, environmental impact assessment and environmental economics. Access to international information on these matters is of enormous value to Australia. Such information would not be available to anywhere near the same extent if Australia were unable to participate in relevant international activities.

As well as those activities from which Australia benefits directly, the Government has a responsibility to participate as a member of the world community in environmental activities of a more global environmental nature, from which all countries stand to benefit in the longer term. The benefits of these activities may not be so immediately evident, but they are nevertheless important. In addition, there are occasions when Australia's participation may constitute part of its aid program-where Australia assists in providing expertise to developing countries through the programs of international environment bodies. In these cases, also, the benefits to Australia are less tangible, but the indirect benefits may be considerable.

Turning to the Standing Committee's findings, the Government agrees with the Committee that international environmental organisations have a valuable role and that the benefits to Australia from involvement in these organisations can be extensive. The Government notes that the Committee recognises that there is considerable scope for improvement in the nature and extent of Australia's participation and that the Committee has made several recommendations aimed at maximising the benefits to Australia.
I wish now to address each of the recommendations in turn, and seek leave to have the text of the Committee's recommendations tabled and incorporated in Hansard at this point.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Recommendations
The Committee recommends that:
1. the Australian Government review the present role of the United Nations Environment Programme to establish its effectiveness; and
as part of this review, the Government examine the level of its funding to the Programme.

2. Australia's continued active participation in the OECD Environment Committee be encouraged and furthered by the provision of the necessary resources to enable expert Australia-based attendance at conferences of its sub-committees to which Australia has made a commitment as a 'participating nation'.
3. the Australian Government maintain its support for and input to the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources; and

to facilitate a greater and more meaningful involvement of non-government organisation members of IUCN, the Commonwealth Government re-examine the feasibility of increasing funding to these organisations to a level sufficient to permit their attendance at IUCN conferences.
4. the Minister for Foreign Affairs prepare and present to the Parliament a definitive statement stipulating guidelines for Australia's involvement in international organisations; and
a mechanism be established to co-ordinate this involvement fully among the Executive Departments.

5. the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment table annually in the Commonwealth Parliament a report or reports on the proceedings and findings of international conferences of an environmental nature which Australia has attended in the preceding 12 months, indicating to the Parliament the response of the Australian Government to the recommendations from each conference.

6. the Department of Home Affairs and Environment circulate, on a regular basis, to Members of Parliament and recognised conservation organisations a list of publications available relating to Australia's involvement in international environmental activities.

7. all reports of international environmental conferences and copies of treaties of an environmental nature be produced in a form suitable for distribution to the general public and be made available for purchase through recognised Government bookshop outlets.

8. the Department of Home Affairs and Environment ensure that copies of selected international publications relating to the environment be obtained in sufficient quantities to enable distribution to Parliamentary libraries, major public libraries and environmental centres and that the feasibility of selling them through Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops be assessed.
9. the adoption of the May 1981 Draft Principles and Procedures for Commonwealth/State Consultation on Treaties be discussed at the earliest available Premiers' Conference.
10. the Commonwealth Government monitor and actively pursue the implementation of international treaties and agreements relating to environmental protection and conservation; and

the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment ensure that the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers and the Australian Environment Council regularly examine the implementation of new and existing treaties and agreements relating to environmental protection and conservation.

11. the Department of Home Affairs and Environment conduct a seminar at regular intervals of Commonwealth Government, State government and non-government representatives to exchange ideas and discuss Australia's approach to international and domestic environmental issues.
12. the Draft National Conservation Strategy for Australia be tabled in Parliament early in 1983 and that it be given full consideration by the Parliament prior to being adopted by the Government.

13. the Commonwealth Government continue to actively support Australia's involvement in Antarctica and provide sufficient resources to enable Australia's high standing within the Antarctic Treaty to be maintained up until 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first recommendation is that the Government review its support for the United Nations environment program. My Department has reviewed the nature and activities of UNEP and Australia's involvement in that program. The review found that UNEP is the key international organisation through which governments address global environmental issues. It found that UNEP has been effective, in its first decade, in co-ordinating and catalysing the environmental component of the many diverse programs of the United Nations; in developing valuable environmental monitoring, assessment and information programs; and in providing the framework for better global and regional co-operation on environmental matters. The Government will continue to participate actively in this program.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's second recommendation is that Australia strengthen its participation in sub-groups of the OECD Environment Committee. The Government acknowledges the considerable direct benefit to Australia of participation in the OECD environment program. We recognise that the major constraint of distance has severely limited participation by Australia-based officers in meetings of the OECD Environment Committee and its major sub-committees. The possibility of increasing the current level of attendance by Australia-based experts is being reviewed in the light of the Standing Committee report. I must make the point that the problem of distance is really severe and cost is a major factor. I do not know how we can overcome it. Departments always face this problem, which most of our colleagues in the OECD do not face. It is only a very short trip for them. It is a very long trip for us. Further consideration is also being given to the possibility of increasing the support for OECD Environment Committee activities provided by the Australian Permanent Mission to the OECD.

The Standing Committee recommends continuing government support for IUCN and consideration of increased funding of non-government organisations to permit attendance at IUCN conferences overseas. The Government continues to support IUCN through its membership and participation programs. On the question of funds for non-government officers to attend IUCN conferences, funds for travel overseas meetings could be sought through the program of grants to voluntary conservation organisations. This program provides grants for general administrative assistance, technical assistance and research. The Government has recently amended the guidelines to allow organisations to use funds granted under the program to send representatives to overseas conferences. The level of funding for the program is decided each year in the Budget context. Honourable members will be aware that the Government has substantially increased the amount provided in both 1983-84 and 1984-85 over the amount available in previous years. My recollection is that the amount has increased from something like $350,000 to in excess of $800,000.

The fourth recommendation is that the Minister for Foreign Affairs should present to Parliament a statement stipulating guidelines for Australia's involvement in international organisations and a mechanism to co-ordinate the involvement of Executive departments. This recommendation has been brought to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). The Minister considers that, in practice, satisfactory guidelines have now been established by the decisions of relevant Ministers since the Government took office. This matter will be kept under review.

The fifth recommendation is that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment table annually a report on proceedings and findings of international conferences of an environmental nature indicating the Australian response to recommendations. This is a very important and far reaching recommendation which the Government has agreed to adopt. The task will entail close liaison and co-operation with relevant departments and authorities to follow up recommendations from conferences of the major international environmental organisations and other conferences of an environmental nature.

Recommendations 6, 7 and 8 address the question of dissemination within Australia of information and material on international environmental matters. I support these recommendations. My Department is examining ways of improving dissemination of information on the work of international environmental bodies to Parliament, conservation groups and the general public. The Committee's recommendation that my Department provide major public libraries with copies of material from international environmental organisations would be unduly demanding on limited resources. However, major libraries will be included on distribution lists for notification of publications and arrangements will be made for borrowing departmental copies through the inter-library loan system.

The recommendation that the feasibility of selling international reports through the Australian Government Publishing Service be assessed has been examined. In general this has not been found to be a feasible proposition. However, I note that the OECD and UNESCO already have Australian distributors for their publications. In relation to the availability of information on treaties, I note that copies of individual treaties are already obtainable through AGPS.

The terms of the Committee's ninth recommendation, that the 1981 draft principles and procedures for Commonwealth-State consultation on treaties be discussed at the earliest available Premiers Conference, have already been met. The draft principles and procedures were drawn up by a Commonwealth-State officials committee in 1980, following an initial decision at the Premiers Conference in 1977 that there was a need to establish sound guidelines for consultation on treaties. The draft principles and procedures were subsequently examined by Premiers and were adopted at the Premiers Conference in June 1982. In November 1983 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) advised Premiers that the Government endorsed the principles and procedures, subject to certain important modifications. These modifications were designed to ensure that ratification of treaties was not unduly delayed and that Australia would not be seen in the international arena as attempting to use its constitutional structure as a shield to avoid or limit its acceptance of treaty obligations.

The Committee's tenth recommendation is that the Government actively pursue the implementation of international treaties and agreements relating to environmental protection and conservation. Within my portfolio, treaties and agreements relating to environment and conservation will be monitored. The Council of Nature Conservation Ministers and the Australian Environment Council will be consulted closely in regard to existing and proposed new treaties and agreements.

Recommendation 11 seeks to have regular seminars involving Commonwealth and State government and non-government representatives to discuss Australia's approach to international and domestic environmental issues. As resources permit, my Department will respond on a case by case basis to this recommendation, through seminars and other consultations.

The twelfth recommendation asks that the draft national Conservation Strategy for Australia be tabled for consideration by Parliament. The Government sponsored a national conference in Canberra in June 1983 to refine the draft which the Committee had before it in 1982. The strategy agreed by consensus at the conference was tabled on 6 December 1983 and was endorsed by the Government in June 1984 on the understanding that endorsement implies agreement with the objectives and strategic principles of the document agreed at the conference.

The final recommendation of the Standing Committee asks the Government to continue support for Australia's involvement in Antarctica and provide sufficient resources to enable Australia's high standing in relation to the Antarctic Treaty to be maintained up until 1991. This is already Government policy. Australia's strong concern to protect the Antarctic environment is well known internationally and is highlighted by the system of measures for environmental protection developed under the Antarctic Treaty. It should be noted, however, that the Committee's reference to 1991 in this recommendation arose from the commonly held but mistaken belief that the Antarctic Treaty will be renegotiated in 1991. It is Australian policy to support the indefinite continuation of the Antarctic Treaty and to maintain our high standing in its forums.

The Government is appreciative of the work of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in preparing this important report on Australia's participation in international environmental organisations.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I make one last comment for the information of honourable members: In June this year the third meeting of the OECD Environment Committee at ministerial level is being held in Paris and I expect to attend. These ministerial meetings occur every five years and review the OECD environment program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join with the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) in complimenting the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on its report entitled 'Australia's Participation in International Environmental Organisations'. I note, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you were a member of that Committee and of the Sub-Committee which carried out this most worthwhile work. I should say in commencing, however, that I am rather dismayed that it has taken nearly two and a half years for the Government to respond to this report. It is not a difficult report. It did not involve any great re-analysis of existing government policies but merely a restatement in a number of areas on what they were meant to be. Nevertheless, as a report it has focused our attention on the need to see Australia's position in relation to the various United Nations and other international environmental organisations and agencies with which we are associated. The purpose of this inquiry was in fact to investigate the role and effectiveness of Australia's participation in those organisations. With due respect to the Minister, I do not feel, on hearing his response, that the Government has really taken seriously the comments made by the Committee because there is very little evidence that apart from saying 'Yes, everything is marvellous' the Government has considered aspects of Australia's participation in these organisations which deserve further examination.

SPEECH.PARA: The report made the important observation that the emergence of environmental protection as a major area of public policy both on a domestic as well as a world-wide scale is relatively recent. It cites the late 1960s as being possibly the commencement of this world-wide trend towards an appreciation of the fact that the environment in which we live influences not only our own generation but certainly those which will follow. Therefore, all governments have a role to play, as members of the United Nations, in trying to maintain an overall world environmental strategy which will be for the long term benefit of the human species and in fact all forms of life on this planet.

The Committee also made the point that many of the issues being considered were inherently international because of their global ecological scope; that local scientific data is often scarce and therefore there is a need to share information; that consultation between nations helps to overcome the differing environmental policies and approaches which nations or people may have in these matters; that there is a need for relationships between environmental, economic, social and political factors to be acknowledged and understood to a greater extent both nationally and internationally; and that more immediate bilateral problems were effectively forcing action by industrialised nations, in particular in Western Europe where trans-frontier pollution is becoming a critical problem. It is worth noting that in the last year or so the European Economic Community has attempted to get all members to agree to a convention for the reduction of atmospheric pollution, but unfortunately it has failed to get the co-operation of a number of states, including the United Kingdom. I think this demonstrates in a very real measure the major problems one faces at the international level in trying to get domestic problems into perspective in this field.

The Minister also made some observations in relation to the problems of atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, the destruction of the ozone layer, the contamination of the oceans, the control of hazardous chemicals, the protection of endangered wildlife and so forth. I think it is rather strange hearing this coming from a Minister of this Government which has put in place what must go down in history as the most inconsistent uranium policy ever known. I think it is worth noting that a large segment of the Australian Labor Party, both in this Parliament and elsewhere, seems to find uranium to be a matter of great concern, essentially because it fears its potential as a pollutant on the one hand and as a means of destroying humanity on the other. It is just as absurd to suggest that iron ore should not be mined because tanks or guns can be made with it just as cars, bridges and other things can. To a large degree the same principle applies to uranium. I think it is worth while noting that the generation of 1,000 megawatts of electricity at a 70 per cent load factor requires the mining and use of 5 1/2 million tonnes of brown coal, 2 1/2 million tonnes of black coal, over 1 1/4 million tonnes of fuel oil or over one million tonnes of natural gas. Yet only 180 tonnes of uranium are required to generate the same amount of electricity. We must consider whether the destructive influences of having a significantly higher level of carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide in the world's atmosphere caused essentially by the use of fossil fuels, both coal and petroleum products, are preferable to the continuation of a sustainable level of uranium mining and the generation of what is in fact one of the cleanest forms of energy known at this stage. Nevertheless, as I said, this is an inconsistent approach which has been developed by this Government and will certainly change with the fall of this Government.

I now refer to a number of the recommendations made by the Committee which have been referred to by the Minister. The report noted that the Government should review its support for the United Nations Environment Program. Again, it is a matter of some regret that in the Minister's comments it is quite clear that this was not done. I draw his attention to page 6 of the Committee's report which, in paragraphs 33 and 34, states:
. . . It is, nevertheless, rather poignant to observe that the following comment was included in the CSIRO submission:

'International programs sponsored by UN agencies and other supranational bodies are generally poorly conceived, badly managed and politically motivated, rather than soundly-based technically and scientifically.
It went on to suggest:

. . . but given that Australia is the 10th largest contributor to the Environment Fund, the Government must ensure that it maintains constant vigilance of the aims and objectives of UNEP and be prepared to speak up at UN General Assembly conferences to ensure the effective continuation of this worthwhile program.

I strongly suggest that we should have a more effective role to play in the Fourth Committee of the United Nations General Assembly which, as I recall, is responsible for budgetary matters concerning the efficiency and effectiveness of the manner in which our funds are spent by United Nations agencies. But this was merely an identification of the problem by the Committee which was not appropriately addressed by the Minister in his remarks. He simply said: 'Yes, my Department has reviewed the nature and activities of UNEP and Australia's involvement in that program will continue'. The report was not questioning Australia's involvement in the program but rather the manner in which the expenditure made by Australia and other countries was being utilised for various global environmental issues. It is not just a case as the Minister said of the Government continuing to participate actively in this program. The question is rather: Are we prepared to examine in detail the objectives of the various undertakings under UNEP and the manner in which public expenditure is being utilised for that purpose?

The report referred to a similar problem in relation to Australian participation in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's Environment Committee. The Minister made the point, for which I have some sympathy, that because of Australia's geographical position in OECD terms, along with possibly New Zealand and Japan, we are the most far-flung members. The rest are either in Europe or in North America. Consequently, a higher cost is borne by Australia if we wish to be adequately represented at OECD functional meetings. Nevertheless, the OECD does have an environment committee and a number of sub-committees which cover areas which are of relevance to developed countries such as Australia. In that context, if we want to be a full member of the OECD, it is clear that we should play a more effective role wherever we possibly can, including membership of the OECD Environment Committee.

Another recommendation made by the Committee referred to continuing government support for the International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources and consideration of increased funding of non-governmental organisations to permit attendance at IUCN conferences overseas. This has been a fairly moot point in recent years. But I make the point that the Fraser Government to the best of my knowledge was the first to permit non-governmental organisations to be represented on Australian delegations overseas. I should note also that this is a practice which has been continued with success by the current Government.

The fifth recommendation is that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment should table annually a report on proceedings and findings of international conferences of an environmental nature, indicating the Australian response to recommendations. This recommendation is of some relevance to other recommendations on the dissemination of information in Australia and also the role which the States should play in the determination of policy in relation to the environment. As all honourable members would recall, as a result of the decision in relation to the Tasmanian dams affair, the Opposition and the Government found themselves diametrically opposed in regard to the handling of environmental issues of this type. It is the strong view of the Opposition that the States must be brought into negotiations through international bodies for the establishment of treaties which will require obligations of a domestic nature which will have an impact upon State law. This is something which the Government, of course, finds some difficulty in living with. This point is in the Minister's comments on the ninth recommendation which were as follows:
In November 1983 the Prime Minister advised Premiers that the Government endorsed the Principles and Procedures-
that is, those relating to co-ordination between the Commonwealth and the States-

subject to certain important modifications. These modifications were designed to ensure that ratification of treaties was not unduly delayed and that Australia would not be seen in the international arena as attempting to use its constitutional structure as a shield to avoid or limit its acceptance of treaty obligations.

Nevertheless, the point needs to be made that many treaties do have a federalism clause included in them. It has always been the practice of previous Australian governments to ensure that our ratification of treaties is subject to the fact that the Australian Constitution does not leave in our hands all power and that many international treaties require the co-operation and support of State governments if they are to be applied within domestic law. Consequently, the observations made by the Minister in that context do not adequately take into account the realities of State involvement and the arrangements instituted by the Fraser Government to ensure that the States were brought into the pre-negotiating stage and, on some occasions, even the negotiating stage, to ensure that there were no difficulties in the implementation of international agreements. There has been a tendency on the part of socialist governments in Australia for many years to go around the world big-noting themselves, signing treaties willy-nilly, regardless of whether they will be applied. If this Government wishes to find itself in the same situation as that of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and other communist governments, so be it. But I see no purpose, and neither does the Opposition, in signing Australia's name to treaties unless we will be able to apply them in relation to domestic law. This is not just a small issue which can simply be passed over; it is a matter of very fundamental importance.

I refer now to the twelfth recommendation of the report, which was that the draft national conservation strategy for Australia should be tabled for consideration by Parliament. The Minister went to some length to make the point that a national conference was established. That is true. He also ignored the fact that the whole concept of the national conservation strategy was developed by the Fraser Government and that that conference had already been set in place before the change of government. Nevertheless, I agree with him that an effective and useful conference was held involving the States and non-governmental organisations as well as other Federal and State authorities and bodies to achieve some consensus on this matter. But the important thing is that the twelfth recommendation quite explicitly stated that the draft national conservation strategy should be tabled for consideration by Parliament. I regret that, in the two years since that conference took place, this Minister and the Government have made not the slightest attempt to have a debate in this Parliament on the introduction of the national conservation strategy, or on what it means for the development of Australia. As we pointed out at the time of that conference, it is essential that all bodies-environmental organisations, miners, farmers, industrialists as well as State and local governments-should be involved. Surely the Federal Parliament of this nation equally has a role to play and a right to have a point of view in matters such as this.

My final observation is related to the question of Australia's involvement in the Antarctic. This was the final recommendation of the Standing Committee, which asked that Australia should continue to support our involvement in Antarctica and provide sufficient resources to enable our high standing in relation to the Antarctic Treaty to be maintained in the future. It is worth noting that the Labor Government has in many ways severely compromised Australia's vital interests in Antarctica. For example, our scientific activity has been severely handicapped by a number of budgetary cutbacks, in particular the 3 per cent real reduction in the expenditure of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in the 1984-85 financial year. Australia now has the same level of annual investment in Antarctica as it had in the mid-1960s. Consequently, the level of Australian scientific activity could be seen to be in steady decline. Professor David Caro, the Chairman of the Federal Government's Antarctic Research Policy Advisory Committee, said that there seems to be no accepted national policy on the Antarctic. He added that the $30m per year currently spent was so inadequate as to be a 'waste of money'. These are real issues which have been raised by the Committee in this report. I am frankly rather unimpressed with the level of consideration which has been given by the Government to these matters. It was not simply a case of having to go through the forms of the House to give a response. This House deserves a response of substance. I regret that in this case it failed to receive it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was addressing the House last Friday in this debate I drew the House's attention to the issue of Aboriginal health. I pointed out that in regard to a wide range of diseases Aborigines fare very poorly compared with non-Aboriginal Australians. In fact, Aboriginals remain the least healthy identifiable sector of the Australian community. While the factors underlying the persistently poor status of Aboriginal health are complex, the major determinant is obviously the extreme social inequality experienced by Aborigines. There is a need for this Government to look more closely at its current policies in respect of Aboriginal health to see whether there are inadequacies and, if so, how they can be improved. We need a national plan for Aboriginal health similar to that which was projected in 1973.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the plight of the Aborigine caught in the criminal justice system. It is a sad fact that Aboriginals are ten times more likely to be imprisoned than non-Aboriginals. In Western Australia, we have one of the highest imprisonment rates for Aboriginals in the Commonwealth. This issue requires urgent attention by State and Federal governments. A research project carried out in 1981 by Mr Broadhurst, of the University of Western Australia's extension service, found that, compared with other Western countries, the community attitudes in Western Australia were more severe and that this could contribute, in part, to Western Australia's high imprisonment rate. Of course, we must remember that it is the sentencer, not public opinion, who determines the sentence. However, it may be that the sentencer's attitude reflects that of the wider community.

I pay recognition to the work of the Aboriginal Legal Service in this respect. There is no doubt in my mind that the high rate of imprisonment to which I have already referred would be much higher but for its existence. All the lawyers, field workers and support staff who work in that service deserve high praise for their work.

I turn now to the issue of youth unemployment. There is concern on both sides of the House at the high level of youth unemployment. The unemployment rate amongst youth, especially those in the 15 to 19 years age group, is higher than for any other age group. According to Windshuttle in 1980, this is not a new phenomenon; only the magnitude of the current rate of unemployment is unprecedented. In 1984 some 23.8 per cent of youth aged 15 to 19 years were recorded as unemployed. The Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs estimates that the real rate of unemployment, including the hidden unemployed, is 33 per cent. The average duration of unemployment among the 15 to 19-year-old group has risen from seven weeks in 1973 to 26.4 weeks in 1984. No honourable member on either side of the House could be satisfied with that state of affairs. According to Benn, today's youth are destined to become the chronically unemployed of the 1990s.

It is generally recognised that the most vulnerable group of unemployed are young school leavers. Many youths who experience unemployment, particularly long term unemployment, have great difficulty in developing a work identity. The crucial months following their departure from school can have significant long term consequences in terms of their work and self-identity. Volunteerism and short term unskilled work are unlikely to instil a sense of work identity, as the Opposition naively advocates.

It was in response to the problems of youth unemployment in particular that the Government set up the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs. The Kirby report addressed itself to many of the issues relating to youth and adult unemployment and made recommendations as to how the structure of labour market programs can be changed to make them more efficient and effective, considering the need for continuing restraint in the growth of public expenditure. However, it does not address many of the more fundamental issues of the nature of the economy and the market system which determines production according to profit rather than social criteria. The Kirby report recognises this shortcoming and acknowledges it as follows:

Even the successful management of the economy is unlikely to redress the unemployment problem. As long as the market remains the arbiter over the conditions of work and living, unemployment will persist.

The Kirby report acknowledges that increased youth unemployment is not due to the failings of schools or individuals. However, it appears to assume that by changing the characteristics of individual unemployed youth, unemployment amongst this group will be reduced by increasing their job prospects. Unfortunately, this is in contradiction to experiences over the past decade, which has seen growing unemployment amongst youth in a period when educational levels amongst this group have risen steadily to an estimated 66 per cent. How is it then that a new program of education will reverse this trend? Higher educational participation does not change the number of available jobs and cannot, therefore, reduce the stock of unemployed. Those with higher education simply displace less qualified people in jobs requiring skills below their level of competence.

The question as to where new jobs are to come from, the crucial issue the Government must address if it is to reduce unemployment, remains unanswered by the Kirby Committee. The Kirby Committee identifies successful macro-economic management as the answer to this problem, but does not tell us what this is. In fairness to the Committee, this was not its brief. However, it is the issue which must be addressed by the Government and, rightly or wrongly, it is a question that many organisations in the community had hoped the Committee would address. This is a question to which the community will continue to seek an answer. I thank the House for its attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the repeated commitment in the Governor-General's Speech known as the trilogy and its relationship to the rigidities that exist in our national, political and economic activity. The so-called trilogy laudably commits the Government to hold the growth in outlays within the rate of growth of the economy. It contains a commitment not to increase the Commonwealth tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product, and says that the deficit will be reduced as a share of GDP as well as in money terms. These are very desirable objectives but, given the rigid nature of Australian Labor Party factions and the entrenched position of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which now exerts an influence over economic policy beyond its representative base, one wonders-and the community is entitled to wonder-whether the Government will be able to meet its commitments and, indeed, whether they go far enough, given the sorry position of Australia, both in terms of its economic performance compared with other trading nations and in terms of the maintenance and improvement of the living standards of its citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been forced for sound economic reasons to make this trilogy commitment because elected representatives from all sides of the political spectrum have not moved from their entrenched position of obtaining votes in the short term at the expense of sound economic practice in the long term. They have all chosen to buy votes rather than sell good government. The result is ever increasing levels of government expenditure funded by increasing levels of taxation and public sector borrowing. As a percentage of GDP, expenditure, taxation and borrowing by the Commonwealth for the periods 1982-83 and 1983-84 are at their highest levels in 30 years. In 1983-84 Federal Government expenditure rose to 30.5 per cent of GDP. Commonwealth taxation took up 24 per cent of GDP. Net borrowings by the Commonwealth Government rose to 3.7 per cent of GDP in the same period. These sorts of levels in government involvement in the economy act as a noose around the neck of non-government economic activity, and, combined with other rigidities in the labour market, in the business sector and in society's attitudes towards the role of government, ensure that this nation is slowly but surely being strangled. If we do not release the noose and free up national incentive so that productive ideas and practices can turn around our declining economic position, and if we do not argue for reductions in the role of the state, then Australia is destined to become the 'White Trash of Asia' or the 'Pacific's Argentina'.

The trilogy, while committing the Government to increases within the rate of growth in the economy, nevertheless still allows for increases in the role of government. This conditioning to inbuilt indexation of government activity is unhealthy and is not in the interests of achieving a smaller role for government and a greater role for the individual. Community leaders and elected representatives have a responsibility to create an environment and a climate of opinion whereby Australians positively support the proposition that government expenditure should be cut in both money and real terms.

It is quite clear that governments are not the creators of wealth and can only give away taxpayers' hard-earned funds, generated in the private sector through the efforts of individuals and corporations. It has become unpopular at all levels of government in Australia to resist the catch-cry that the government should fix it. This inevitably means spending or regulating. As President Reagan said in his budget message:

At some point, the collective demands on the public treasury of all special interests combined, exceed the public's ability and willingness to pay. The single most difficult word for a politician to utter is a simple flat 'no'.

The American President has made commendable efforts to reduce the American deficit of $US222 billion to $US180 billion. Meanwhile, the Hawke Labor Government has shown its irresponsible attitude towards Budget deficits during its period of office by increasing the cumulative debt of this nation to approximately $20 billion, when with a surge in revenue resulting from the breaking of the drought, the wages pause and increased business profitability it had a glorious opportunity to reduce Australia's deficit.

I now turn to the rigidities in the labour market and industrial relations system which have resulted in a cost structure putting Australian industry at a trading disadvantage compared with our overseas partners. It has led to a situation where the majority of our export potential comes from unprocessed or semi-processed resources from the mining and agricultural sectors. This rigidity has cost our citizens, especially our young people, dearly in terms of jobs. The report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs cites the consequences of excessive wage rates and rigid relativities. Some 2.4 per cent of the work force was unemployed in 1970, whereas 8.6 per cent was unemployed in 1984. A wider definition encompassing the 'hidden unemployed' would show that 12.6 per cent was unemployed in 1977 but 18.6 per cent in 1983. But while the extent of unemployment has worsened, the severity of the duration has also worsened. In 1970 the average duration of unemployment for an unemployed person was 7.3 weeks and the number of people unemployed for more than six months was 6.5 per cent of the total unemployed. By 1984, the average duration had risen to 45.5 weeks and the number of unemployed for more than six months was more than 50 per cent of the total number of unemployed. Consequently, in 1970 0.1 per cent of the working age population was receiving unemployment benefits. By 1984 this figure had risen to 5 per cent.

As a result, unemployment and sickness benefits made up 2.5 per cent of the social security budget in 1959-60, whereas by 1984-85 the percentage in the Federal Budget had risen to 19.3. This cost in both social and budgetary terms is significant. The loss of self-esteem to the unemployed themselves, combined with the loss to the nation of their skills, provides a major human and financial problem for policy makers in the next decade. Warwick Bracken in the Canberra Times on 5 February 1985 argued:

Unemployment figures are a direct result of the failure of the wage fixation system. Australia's unemployment is too high because wages are too high and Australia's youth unemployment is two to three times the average unemployment rate because youth wages are too high relative to adult wage rates.
He went on:
Most economists agree that a decline in real wages relative to productivity is necessary for employment to grow and unemployment to fall.
One of the Government's own advisers, Mr Alan Brackart, Director of the Office of Youth Affairs, has said:
We do not need to know to what extent relative wage levels causes youth unemployment to conclude that a substantial reduction in youth wages would reduce youth unemployment.

No amount of expensive make work programs, which provide menial work for short periods for the chronically unemployed, will cover up the victims of Australia's out-of-date, rigid and inflexible wage-fixing and arbitration system. Unless we move to a more decentralised industrial system, without arbitration commissions and where governments have no role, except in negotiating employment contracts with their own employees, and these wage and condition contracts should not be allowed to exceed comparable contracts in the non-government sector; we will continue to export less, shed jobs and burden the few in work with higher levels of taxes and charges to recompense the victims of our inflexible system and misguided policies. One has only to look at those countries where the philosophy of unionism is to assist in job creation and where market forces determine contracts between employer and employees and where wage indexation has been abandoned, to see the results in terms of jobs and productivity. Marvin Kosters, from the American Enterprise Institute, had this to say:
The radical decline in the US inflation rate and the rapid generation of new jobs in the United States economy has been much facilitated by America's labourers willingness to make concessions.

In 1983 when some five million jobs were created in the United States, wage reductions accepted were higher than in 1982, when the United States economy was in recession. A third of the workers covered by new contracts in manufacturing experienced actual reductions in pay. To quote the Institute of Public Affairs:

In the first six months of 1984 with US unemployment down 30 per cent from its recession peak, wage increases negotiated by unions only represent an average annual wage rise of 2.8 per cent, hardly the inflation rate, which is in the 3 to 4 per cent range. Given that productivity has been rising 5 to 6 per cent, American business is enjoying a profits bonanza, which is paying off for the US economy in improvements of corporate balance sheets and a surge in new investment in plant and equipment and record levels of new business formation.

That is what has been happening in America where a flexible labour market gets the results with new jobs, reduced unemployment, profit and job creation and, what is more, the system receives overwhelming public support. Meanwhile, we slide backwards. It can be further argued that wage indexation systems which lock a country into a rigid structure of absolute real wage and relative wage rates, irrespective of general economic conditions and irrespective or which industries are expanding or contracting, are, to say the least, inflexible and indeed counter-productive to the individual and general good. There is evidence to suggest that the countries which have the most flexible labour markets have done relatively well with respect to employment growth.

Mr Emile van Lennep, the Secretary-General of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, when commenting on this matter in November 1983, pointed to the contrast between North America and Europe, both with roughly similar investment trends, but differing degrees of labour market flexibility. He said:
During the past decade, employment growth in North America was more than 10 times as great as Europe.
He went on:

Even when aggregate investment was not particularly high, greater labour mobility, more flexible real and relative wages, and perhaps other factors related to the freedom for entrepreneurial initiative in small or new enterprises, led to the rapid creation of new jobs. In Japan, because of the capacity of the service sector to absorb or shed workers and the wage flexibility provided to larger enterprises by the bonus system, the degree of flexibility has been roughly similar.

The OECD economic outlook in July 1983 showed, on a scale of real wage rigidity and productivity, that the performance of Japan was far ahead of Europe and slightly ahead of the United States, in terms of high productivity performance and low levels of wage rigidity. With regard to wage indexation, the OECD economic outlook of December 1983 suggests:
It is because of the harmful effect of full wage indexation on employment and output that it has been abandoned in Belgium, Netherlands, Denmark, Italy, France and Switzerland.

Meanwhile, we pursue a course to our disadvantage with that unelected partner to the Government benches, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which consistently argues for full indexation with no regard to the cost of new jobs, let alone existing jobs, to say nothing of our competitive position against imports, domestically, or exports abroad. I urge the Government to continue with a deregulated approach to our wage fixing and arbitration system, just as it has done in the financial arena.

The Government has continued on from the Fraser Government, in introducing changes to the financial markets as recommended by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for implementing these important deregulatory changes and granting licences to overseas banks. Such changes can only result in a more market orientated approach and a competitive atmosphere in the investment and money market. So I urge the Government to be consistent in its approach to deregulation, and to dismantle the rigidities that exist in its approach to the pattern of government expenditure and to labour market operations. There is another area of rigidity which is working to the nation's disadvantage and that is our rigid approach to industrial change. In the Bulletin of February 1985, John Edwards noted:

'The three committees of inquiry since 1965 have pointed out that Australia's rate of growth since World War 2 has lapsed behind those of comparable countries. Australia exported a smaller share of its national output than did most countries of its size and wealth and imported correspondingly less. Other countries had achieved a faster rate of growth by specialising more in what they did well; Australia had specialised up to a point and then developed a manufacturing industry which could only survive behind some of the world's highest tariff and quota barriers.
Professor Max Cordin of the Australian National University, has said:
Australia developed a policy which discriminated against exports as well as imports.

But, as most reports have established, protection against imports has not protected jobs in manufacturing. The Bulletin article went on to say that even though the average level of protection in the Australian economy has declined from 35 per cent to 26 per cent in the past decade, and while only four of the twelve major manufacturing industries have greater than the average protection of 26 per cent, two groups-cars and textiles, clothing and footwear-account for 40 per cent of the consumer cost of protection in Australia'. The article stated that political pressure has been such that even though these 'most highly protected industries employ only 3 per cent of the work force-their protection has increased mightily, but employment has fallen'. According to Tom Hogg, Director of the Australian Manufacturing Council Secretariat:

Those industries which grew most rapidly over the period, generally had above average capital intensity with above average labour productivity, or a high degree of natural protection or export capability. Those which grew very slowly were labour-intensive, or with markets confined to the slowly expanding economy.

There is another rather insidious side to the tariff question. Tariffs have become very convenient revenue raisers for government, with little or no political cost or outcry. Budget statements show that Customs duty on imports accounted for $841m in 1974-75 but $2,329m in 1983-84. So import duty now contributes 4.8 per cent to total receipts. The estimate for 1984-85 is $2,720m, an increase of 16.8 per cent from 1983-84. So one could be forgiven for wondering whether governments might not have a vested interest in maintaining tariff barriers, especially of the revenue raising variety.

The problem we face is: If protection should be reduced, at what pace should we dismantle the tariff barriers? There is also the question of what form the assistance should take. Should governments have to justify their political decision to assist a national industry against unfair, or even fair competition, from imports? Should they have to do it by way of direct subsidy to the particular industry, thereby forgoing revenue and incurring Budget expenditure, or should they be allowed to hide behind import duty or an inequitable quota system and cause the consumer to bear the cost and pay the price for a decision made on political grounds? These are the questions that need to be addressed, and we should address them with an open mind, putting aside our vested interests, but with the long term good of the nation as the criterion. In conclusion, if rigid ideas, practices and structures are not attacked, not only will the trilogy be a farce, but future growth and prosperity will be only a pipe-dream, and we could well be asking Singapore and Japan for overseas aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this Address-in-Reply debate I would like to address myself to some of the points alluded to by His Excellency the Governor-General in his most gracious Speech at the opening of the Thirty-fourth Parliament. Before doing so, I welcome new members to this House and say to them that if they have come here bringing the prevailing prejudices of their electorates they will be in good company. If they have come here hoping to influence the course of events and to bring new ideas, I say to them: 'You have a hard road to hoe, and you have my sympathy'.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to turn my attention to the reindustrialisation of Australia. Our capacity in this regard has been raped over the last 30 years of events presided over by Liberal governments. I am confident that we can make anything in Australia but we should resist that temptation. We should concentrate on the manufacture of those things we do well. Nothing happens in isolation. Military purchasing is a vital cog in the wheels of reindustrialisation. In the past this has been almost totally ignored by the military, and its performance in this area has been extremely bad. In the inevitable cycle of fashion there are some new centurions who would take us down the Argentinian road. Just as the military junta of the Argentine met its Waterloo in the Falkland Islands, so will we meet our Waterloo if we allow them to take us down that road.

The impending submarine purchase by this Government will be the biggest item of capital procurement undertaken for some time. Already I am confident that it has the hallmarks of another FA18 exercise, the demonstrable incompetence of which will weigh heavily on the wrong side of the ledger for many years to come. Last week Senator MacGibbon was quoted as saying that Australian Labor Party factions were responsible for holding up the submarine decision. This is simply not true, although my faction has taken a very keen interest in the submarine project definition study, and it continues to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which faction?

—My faction represents some of the most sensible and forward-looking ideas in the Parliament. It is a very small faction and at present I am the only member. I disagree entirely with Senator MacGibbon. I feel it is the responsibility of people such as me to take an interest in these matters, particularly when one is presented with the military's record. But we need have no fear for I am becoming painfully aware that as a back bencher I can have no impact in this area and the Ministry will go on endorsing the military as it did under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware that the choice of contenders for the project definition study has been decided by the submarine study group and their names will be forwarded to Cabinet, where, in the normal course of events, they will undoubtedly be endorsed. This was no doubt the reason for the outrageous article in the Australian Financial Review of last Friday under the byline of Peter Robinson. This has all the hallmarks of an official leak from the Navy and I am confident that I could put names to that source. I prophesy now that the two contenders chosen for the PDS will be HDW-IKL, one of the German contenders, and Kockumus, a Swedish contender. The reason for this article was no doubt to make it easier for the Navy to justify its choice. I might say that it would not in the least surprise me if the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) was a party to this action.

It seems to be fashionable in Australia today to bash the Poms. Anglophobia is rampant in the armed forces, with the exception of this Army, and I suspect that it springs from some macho desire of the military to assert its independence. It conveniently overlooks the fact that it has been many years since the British exercised any real influence. Our areas or subservience today lie elsewhere. The article in the Australian Financial Review blames the British for just about everything since Jesus wore short pants. For instance, Mr Robinson blames the British for the IBM and Japanese Facom fiasco. He blames the British for the calling of revalidation of tenders which gave rise to a six-month delay. The truth is, of course, that the Minister, of his own volition, called for its revalidation because he was understandably far from happy with things as they were.

Mr Robinson talks about the commercial blundering and incompetence of many British firms. He is quite right. For instance, Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering Ltd would have been far better served had it duchessed selected journalists as the other contenders did, or had it inundated us with glossy brochures as their competitors did, most of which had absolutely nothing to do with submarines. Vickers merely addressed itself to the submarine project and what it could do for Australian industry. Vickers's original submission was pathetic but, because of a palace coup, Vickers lifted its game enormously and set out to win the contract. The Navy's only concern should be to get the very best deal for Australia. The Navy should forget its emotional arguments and concern itself only with technical competence, and in this area the British are good. For whatever motives, the Navy wants the HD10 submarine. As early as last June I thought this was apparent. However, asking us to accept two paper boats is an act of extreme irresponsibility.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Royal Australian Navy specified in its request for tender that it sent out to all contestants that it be a design or a derivative of a proven in-service design of demonstrable performance and reliability and that it constitute a low technical risk for the Commonwealth. It further spelt out that the submarine to be selected should preferably have been built and introduced into service or there should be good evidence of a sponsoring government intending that it should enter service before 1986 so that it could be assessed from trial results before a submarine contract was entered into that the technical products risks were low. The minimum requirement should be that the design be a derivative of a proven in-service design of demonstrable performance and reliability. Further, any modification to the submarine platform and combat system to meet the RAN's unique requirements must be possible at low risk and within an acceptable cost. The Navy's response has been to choose two submarines, neither of which will ever be in service in their host countries, and the performance of which cannot be verified before Australia proceeds to its own decision.

During our Committee's deliberations I was amused when the spokesman for the Swedish contender told us how he had served in the Royal Navy in Oberons and, with an expansive wave of his hand, virtually dismissed the entire expertise of the Royal Navy, conveniently overlooking, of course, that the British had built nine new classes of submarine since its highly successful Oberon.

HDW, in the paper presented to us, went to great pains to explain how it is the best. It chose to denigrate the technologies embodied in nuclear submarines with all the gall of a commercial Cassius Clay and expected us to accept its chest-thumping as fact. I should like now to quote from the highly respected magazine Sea Power, the official publication of the Navy League of the United States of America, which quotes Secretary of the Navy, John F. Lehman Jr, as saying:

The HDW design was found to have some attractive features but does not meet the current American standards relating to submarine silencing, safety, maintainability and manning. In order for a German design submarine to be sufficiently upgraded to be acceptable for United States submarine operation, it would be necessary for the Government of the United States to convey an extraordinary amount of engineering development and design technology to the Germans. The transfer of this information would eliminate the exclusive United States control of the advance submarine silencing technology that currently provides much of the advantage that United States submarines have over those of other nations.

HDW's reply to this was simply a note in its submission saying that a paragraph of an article which appeared in US Sea Power, Volume 10 of 1982 at page 69, is completely without foundation. It does not make it clear whether it is saying that Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman never said those things or whether the Secretary of the Navy did not know what he was talking about.

In any case, it did not refute the even more damning references on page 71 of the same publication. It also attributed the poor showing of the Argentinian submarines in the Falklands contest to the inexperience and lack of training of the Argentinian crews. One might well ask why the Argentinians had decided to get Thyssen, the other German company, to build their new submarines.

I might say that the article in Sea Power magazine was based on a United States House of Representatives Committee on Armed Services, Sea Power and Strategic and Critical Material Sub-committee of 11 March 1982. Admiral Thunman appeared before the Committee and compared the theoretical noise levels of the HDW 2000, although it must be remembered that this ship has not yet been built, with the known noise levels of the American SSN 688 class nuclear submarine. Although for obvious security reasons the figures have been deleted, it is equally obvious from the text of the article that the HDW 2000 did not compare favourably. It is also interesting to note that in the same hearing, the price of the HDW 2000 to the American Government was quoted as $200m in 1982 dollars. It is now being offered to us some three years later for $150m. I suggest to honourable members of this Parliament that there has to be a credibility gap in that difference. Incidentally, this paper is freely available from the United States Information Service, which provides an excellent facility for people prepared to undertake the necessary research.

In the Bulletin of March this year, a well-known Australian defence reporter, John Stackhouse, said that the best the submarine technologies in the free world are held by the British and the Americans, usually in a shared pool. He also said:

Rightly or wrongly, the Western Alliance of which Australia is part regards Sweden as insecure. There is evidence that the Russians have penetrated the Swedish defence system. If we enter into an intimate partnership with the Swedes on a submarine project, we will find advanced Western technologies withheld from us by the Americans and the British, who lead the world in such fields as stealth for submarines. Furthermore, there is an element of technology risk as the Swedes have built only small boats suitable for Baltic use. We need a submarine of double the size to provide range and advance weapon systems capability.

He made many more salient points in that article, which I also commend to honourable members. However, I think that last quote is the nub of the matter, for what the Navy has done to us in its desire to see that it gets the submarine of its heart's desire is to team the Swedish boat with the German boat in the project definition study. The Swedish boat will inevitably sink from sight, wrecked on the very rocks that Mr Stackhouse has outlined. This will, of course, leave only one contender in the field. I feel a sense of frustration and outrage that we are once more being placed in double jeopardy at the behest of the Navy.

Mr Adam Butler, the British Minister of Defence Supply, during his recent visit to Australia, gave an assurance that should the Vickers type R2400 be chosen, the Royal Navy wold modify all its subsequent purchases to provide greater commonality with the Australian ships. This would ensure that, should any problems arise, they would have to be fixed by the Royal Navy. It also opens the door for Australian industry participation in the supply of some components for their construction. HDW of course has also offered this. The difference is that there is no German order for the HDW 2000 and there is unlikely to be one. The choice of the Vickers submarine, teamed with the German submarine on the project definition study, would ensure that we had the benefit of the vast $1.5 billion annually that Britain spends on research and development in the defence area, a large part of which is spent directly on submarines. The other option provides a very good chance of a scenario where Australia, will pay for the research and development of the other country's submarines, so that the companies can in turn on-sell them to other countries. If the Navy is so confident that it has made the right choice with the HDW submarine, let it be pitted against Vickers in a project definition study. Let us see how it shapes up against the verifiable figures that we will be able to obtain from Britain before production commences. In terms of Australian industry, the British will have already gone down the learning curve as its first submarine will be sailing before we commence production. While all the contenders said that, yes, they would build all six submarines in Australia, the British were the only group which said that it preferred to build them all in this country. I put to honourable members that there were two reasons for reluctance on the part of the others. Firstly, they have little work for their own shipyards and, secondly, they are not confident enough of their design and would seek to have construction of the first model in their own yards so that they can do preliminary de-bugging before they move to this country. Members of the Industry Committee will be meeting this week with members of the submarine project team. They will no doubt attempt to convince us that they have made the right choice. They may find us marginally harder than Senator MacGibbon, although I do not doubt for one minute their expertise in the art of snowing. I note from the article in the Australian Financial Review that that process is already under way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I inform you and the House that during the last few months I have been on a search for the trilogy. I had heard of this trilogy and I went looking for it. I had to try to identify it, define it and see exactly what it was. It has taken me months to track the trilogy down. I think I have it, but I am not certain because it depends on who one talks to and what journals one reads as to whether one really thinks one has one's hands on the trilogy. It was a fascinating search and study because the only definition of the trilogy I could find was when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spoke at the National Press Club. In his policy speech to the electorate prior to the 1 December election last year, the Prime Minister did not mention the trilogy as such, but the trilogy came up at at the National Press Club as the major effort to convince Australians that the Labor Party should be voted back. This is what the Prime Minister said at the National Press Club when he launched the trilogy:

SPEECH.PARA: In our next three year term of Government-
the overall level of taxation will not increase as a proportion of the gross domestic product;
the deficit will not increase as a proportion of Gross Domestic Product;
Government spending increases will be restrained below the rate of economic growth.

That, in fact, is the trilogy. I found the trilogy but I could not understand what it meant. That was my dilemma, so I went in search of interpreters. I have acknowledgment from my friends opposite that they do not know what it is either. It depends to whom one talks as to what the trilogy is. The first thing that caught my eye was the factor of the deficit. I had to find out about the deficit, so I went looking and I found all sorts of estimates on it. The most modest estimate came from the permanent building societies of Australia. They said they reckoned the deficit was about $90 billion this year. That is a lot of money. It represents $13,500 for each employed person in Australia. That is the amount that everybody is in hock. That is the size of the debt that individuals have to pay back. That is all tied in with the trilogy. There is an interest rate factor as well, of course, and the interest rate liability for individuals and employees around Australia is about $800 per person per year. That is $16 per week down the drain. Nobody sees it. It goes straight in with our tax to pay the nation's debt. We still have to pay off the principal somewhere along the track. I presume that is the Government's intention, and I presume that is part of the trilogy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to go into surplus first.

—We have to go into surplus, yes. We then have to find extra money to pay back that $90 billion. My honourable friend is right. I went further in my examination of the deficit question and found that, despite public sector borrowing requirements last year, the deficit, the public sector debt, was about 8 per cent of gross domestic product. That is treble what it was three years ago. That is not a bad effort. This Government, in a couple of years, has been able to treble the size of the public sector deficit. It is evident that there has been pressure in financial markets or funds to make sure that we pay for this deficit. The same thing has happened in the United States of America to a fair extent. I found the definition of the trilogy and I found that it contained a really big deficit. The deficit was an important factor in the trilogy.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to know a bit more about what Australians actually owed and what their debt was. I found that one can look at an internal debt or an external debt. I looked at the net external debt because I felt that it would give me an idea of where Australia stood in the world. The net external debt as a proportion of our gross domestic product, which seems to be the term to which everything is related in the trilogy, was about 11 per cent in 1970. In June 1975 it was about 3.5 per cent and in 1980 it was 6 per cent. In June 1984 the net external debt had grown to about 16 per cent of our gross domestic product. Wow! I was starting to get worried about trilogies by that stage. I know that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), who is at the table, has a great interest in housing and in balancing the population of Australia. When he finished his job as Minister for Housing and Construction he would have been really concerned to have new Australians coming into this country and finding that they had to pay off $16 a week as soon as they hit our shores, with a massive principal debt to repay after that. On top of that, those people would know that the factors contained in the public debt had risen three times in the last few years and that the estimated net external debt on the country was about 16 per cent. That is a matter about which people in Australia should be very concerned, particularly those people coming to Australia.

I then tried to find out what the Prime Minister was saying about the trilogy. I was fascinated when I read the speech he made to the Australian people prior to the election and then followed it up by reading his address to the Press Club. Again I quote an extract from the Prime Minister's trilogy of promises on 5 December:
And I repeat the commitment I have made on behalf of the Labor Government of Australia:
In our next three year term of government-
the overall level of taxation will not increase as a proportion of gross domestic product;
the deficit will not increase as a proportion of Gross Domestic Product;
Government spending increases will be restrained below the rate of economic growth.

And when I say that no previous Prime Minister, no previous Australian Government, has given so clear a forward commitment, it is because no previous Government has been able to establish the conditions which make such a commitment achievable.
I wondered about that and I found that Mr Hawke went on to say that Cabinet had considered all of this and that it would give him the right, in September, to go out-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister, not Mr Hawke.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I will certainly follow the forms of the House.

I needed to go to a person called Mr Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald. I wanted his opinion because these learned writers know the Government and members of the Government well. The only trouble was that a group called the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development came along, gave the Australian economy a bit of a quick once over and said: 'There is no way that the Australian economy is going to grow by about 4 per cent. We reckon it is going to grow about 2 1/4 per cent. That is the best we can put on it'. The Treasurer's claim that there is going to be massive growth will not be realised. Of course, the Treasurer flew into a rage and wrote letters to the OECD saying that it did not know what is was talking about. TALK.START.PARA: —Did he give his medal back?

—The OECD is right.

—It appears that the OECD is right, the Treasurer has finally accepted that it is right and the Government is going to base its Budget on a much smaller growth figure than we originally thought would be the case. SPEECH.PARA: The problem with adhering to the trilogy concept is that there are other promises and other bids out around the place. For instance, we have been told that there are going to be tax cuts and tax restructuring. I know that the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), who has farmers in his electorate, and my friend the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who has good business people and workers in his electorate, really want to see the Government succeed. If one looks at the figures one will see that the result really depends on how much effort Australia puts in this year-on how good we will be this year. The fact is that wages are going up about twice as fast as the cost of living. That is a real problem. Australia's competitive capacity is complicated by things such as serious strikes and stoppages which interfere with our export earning capacity on world markets. They will be paying for the accord and for the Government's failure to take hard decisions. They will be paying for a catchcry which is a substitute for hard decisions and good policies.
