Last week the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) announced that the Special Broadcasting Service multicultural television is now to be spread to Perth, Hobart and Darwin. That is very good news for the ethnic communities in those cities and it certainly represents an important improvement in the lives of members of those communities. Today the Minister tabled in the House the report of the Connor Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service, which inquired into the role of multicultural broadcasting in Australia. I am very pleased to see that one of the recommendations of the Connor Committee is with respect to the time sharing of facilities. Paragraph 2.26 of the synopsis of the Connor Committee states:
. . . we have supported their access--
the access of public television-
on the agreed basis, to some Channel 0/28 airtime, and we have recommended that public television organisations be used by multicultural television as one source of local input into programming.

I suggest that the development of Channel 0-28 services in Perth offers a very good opportunity for the ethnic communities in my electorate, particularly the Italian, Macedonian, Yugoslav and Greek communities as well as the Burmese and Chinese. They will not only have access to a facility that is currently operating in Melbourne and Sydney but hopefully also see that public television will be engaged in some time sharing and will add to the output of Channel 0-28 in Perth. That is one area in which I am very pleased to see the Government moving and extending its broadcasting operations and offerings for the community.

Another issue of concern is the issue of the first home owners scheme and its future in the context of the current Cabinet expenditure review. I know there is concern in the community, particularly among those associated with housing, that the first home owners scheme should continue. This is an area of great success for this Government, in marked contrast to the previous Government. We have seen a very substantial improvement in that we are looking at commencement rates of about 135,000 in the first year of operation of the first home owners scheme, compared with 106,000 under the previous Government, which was a 20-year low for housing commencements. The first home owners scheme has been a linchpin. I know that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who is at the table, is very involved in housing and is keen to see housing flourish. I believe that it is very important that we as a Government continue the first home owners scheme under the current arrangements.

I was very concerned last week to see a Press release dated 21 March from the Real Estate Institute of Australia under the name of Kevin Sullivan, President of the Institute, but attributed to the Institute's media contact, Mr Ged Lawrence, which talked about government expenditure being an obscenity. My concern is that the Real Estate Institute itself has benefited substantially from the first home owners scheme in terms of improved turnover and the number of sales throughout Australia. In its Press release it did not pay attention to the fact that sometimes government expenditure results in a net gain to the community in terms of incomes generated, tax taken from those incomes, the level of employment that has been generated and the activity of business. I suggest to the Real Estate Institute that it should look very carefully before it makes blanket statements criticising government expenditure. I think it is understood on this side of the chamber that government expenditure can at times be wasteful. In terms of the cost effectiveness of government expenditure, the first home owners scheme is very successful. I believe that comments like those from the Real Estate Institute do not help the debate when one is trying to argue in the context of government expenditure that the first home owners scheme should be maintained at an effective level.

The third issue to which I refer is the community employment program, which has been another area of success for this Government. We have had some teething problems with the community employment program in my electorate of Stirling. The local government authority, the City of Stirling, has played a less than active role in relation to community employment from May 1984. I am pleased to note that as of two weeks ago it intends to get involved in supporting community employment at a substantial level. I welcome that because in the electorate of Stirling, in the areas covered by the three offices of Mirrabooka, Innaloo and Mount Hawthorn, there is an unemployment rate in excess of 7 per cent of the employed throughout Western Australia. Unfortunately, the level of CEP funding in Stirling is about 4 per cent of the total CEP funding, so we are below quota. What I urge upon the City of Stirling, the major local government authority in the electorate of Stirling, I also urge upon the regional advisory committee for the CEP. I urge both of those bodies to provide substantial support for the CEP. I believe that we can do much for young people in particular with the CEP.

In talking about young people, I wish to address as the fourth issue youth unemployment. The Government has committed itself in a major way to dealing with youth unemployment. We have the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs and the report of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development on youth unemployment and attitudes towards labour market programs. The emphasis of the Government is on training. We have reduced the level of unemployment amongst young people fairly substantially in the time we have been in government, from about 26 per cent to 22 per cent. So we have improved the position of unemployed young people, but obviously it is not satisfactory in government to talk about unemployment at that level. We are seeking to do something about improving the access of young people to jobs.

There are a number of approaches to take-an educational role, an employment role, an income support role and a labour market program role. We see all of those roles as being a part of an approach to youth unemployment. However, I think the Opposition has made some points that do not really add to the debate. The Opposition, through its spokesperson on youth-or, perhaps, in the light of what I am about to say, I should say the spokesperson on youth exploitation-has been talking about deregulating youth wages. That is a very unfortunate approach because there is an emphasis on cutting wages for young people but very little emphasis on training. We, for our part, put much of our emphasis upon the idea of training and getting young people more mobile in the work place.

It is important to emphasise that the Opposition seems to be very much preoccupied with getting the market mechanism to work totally with respect to youth wages, to so deregulate youth wages and to so cut youth wages that young people themselves are put in the position of having to face increased market pressure in order to obtain jobs. The only outcome would be a reshuffling of unemployment. The Kirby report talks about that. If we cut youth wages all we do is put mature age workers out of work in exchange for youth. That philosophy also carries with it an assumption-it is explicitly stated by the Opposition and the Opposition spokesperson on youth matters-that it should be possible for young people to bargain with employers in the context of settling youth wages. That is a very naive position because it assumes that a 16- or 17-year-old is going to be in a position to go to an employer and bargain about what should be deemed to be a living wage or a reasonable wage. Anyone who understands anything about the mechanisms of the labour market will understand that already there is exploitation of people in the market-place for labour. Otherwise why does the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, through its award inspectorate branch, have to spend so much time chasing up underpayments and award breaches? There is an enormous number of underpayments and award breaches. I add that some of the worst areas of exploitation happen to be in relation to women and particularly migrant women.

The other areas of potential exploitation relate to young people. What disturbs me greatly is that the Opposition is sanctioning that. The Opposition is saying: 'Let us deregulate youth wages; let's open up the system'. So not only are we leaving the situation where exploitation can occur but also, by a structural change, we in fact may be encouraging youth exploitation. What we are really looking at is a situation which is unacceptable. I suppose we are really talking about a cut price youth supermarket. It is interesting that we use the term supermarket because if we focus upon two areas of youth employment-fast food outlets and supermarkets-and we talk about the Opposition's perception, we find that there are very few career prospects on offer for young people in supermarkets and fast food outlets.

All that the Opposition and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) are suggesting we should do is deregulate the wages so that those employers can pay less for young people than they currently are and still pursue the practice, which they currently pursue, of sacking them after two years of work. How many people who go into fast food outlets or supermarkets see mature age workers? I suggest to members of the Opposition-if they are capable of seeing this, and perhaps they are not-that in fact the majority of people employed in supermarkets and fast food outlets are young people. That is not because somehow the employers are very philanthropic in their employment practices. In fact, they are currently exploiting a market situation.

If one talks to the parents and to the young people-I suggest to honourable members opposite that that would be a worthwhile practice to introduce some reality into the debate-one finds that very often those young people who are employed in fast food outlets and supermarkets are sacked after working there for two years. Someone who is younger than them moves in in their place. In our view, as a government responsible for the development of young people, that is unacceptable. A cut price youth supermarket-be it a fast food outlet, a supermarket or wherever-in which young people receive the lowest possible rate of pay is an unacceptable approach to dealing with the issue of youth unemployment.

The problem is that always lurking in the minds of some of those honourable members opposite who call themselves the economic dries are the theories of Adam Smith in 1776 and the Wealth of Nations in which Adam Smith was talking about a completely free market. The history is very much against them. What happened was that we also had the theories of Charles Darwin. Darwin in fact postulated that if a species begins to die out it is because, in a sense, it is an inferior species. One can put the two theories together. The theory of Adam Smith, which says 'Leave the market to do what it will', means that we would get massive exploitation of people, as we saw the industrial revolution in Britain. The theory of Darwin says that if a species is dying out that is what it deserves. If one puts those two theories together one provides almost a theoretical sanction of what the Opposition is suggesting-if people are poor, if people are not well off and if people are exploited, it is their own doing; it is because they do not have the will to get themselves organised.

That is implicit in the dries' argument, but it is very much without substance. In the long 200-year history of the illnesses of the industrial revolution people were grossly exploited. I do not think anyone can substantially deny that people were exploited by those theories. Now, in 1985, people are shuffling into this place opposite us and suggesting that those theories should be dredged up again, that somehow Adam Smith can be made respectable and that if young people happen to be exploited it is their own doing because they had it coming to them. I do not see how any society can sanction that position, even if the Opposition argues it.
It is also unfortunate that last week a proposal was put forward by a spokesperson for McDonald's, the hamburger chain. He said:

The McDonald's hamburger chain could employ 1000 more 15-year-olds if the rate of pay was cut to $90 a week, the head of the Australian branch of the company, Mr Peter Ritchie, said in Perth yesterday.
Paying $90 a week to 15-year-olds would not be slashing wages-it would be doubling the dole they get now---

That is an example of the sort of pernicious argument that is taken up by the Opposition in the context of youth unemployment. I might add that it fails to recognise that McDonald's has employment practices which are less than desirable. I go back to this point: How many people of mature age are employed in McDonald's hamburger outlets? The answer is very few, because there are no career paths or prospects. All McDonald's is seeking to do is somehow to reduce youth wages so that it can expand its profit margin. There is no talk about training. Training for what-to slice tomatoes or onions?

What kind of a preposterous position do we have? It is interesting that when we talk to people in the industry in Western Australia we find a wide variety of operators. Kentucky Fried Chicken, Red Rooster, Hungry Jack's, Pizza Hut, Chicken World and Chicken Treat all have industrial relations practices which are acceptable and which the union group dealing with them finds agreeable. Why is it that whenever there are complaints about one particular outlet-it is the sort of outlet that the Opposition pals up with; that is, the McDonald's hamburger chain-the complaints relate to the McDonald's hamburger chain and to employees, usually 17 or 18-year-olds, who have just been fired by McDonald's? If that is the sort of industrial relations approach honourable members opposite want, they should by all means go ahead. By all means they should take that position and endorse it fully. That is youth exploitation. That is not training, not development of young people, not the offering of options and not a seeking to build in an educational component, but simple youth exploitation. That is a farce and it is an example of the sort of farcial theory advanced.

The problem is that the Opposition does not even have a wages policy yet. In the absence of a wages policy what we are getting is, again, a resort to this market notion. Unfortunately, honourable members opposite have not learned or remembered their history. I think the position they are arguing for in respect of youth unemployment is very unsatisfactory. How can they come into this place and talk about exploitation of young people by arguing that their wages could be cut? That also flies in the face of the reality that already there is considerable diversity of wages in terms of award wages being offered in the market-place. These wages have been negotiated through the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. There has been a substantial variation from 100 per cent to 60 per cent of another rate of pay.

I do not think the Opposition has really taken on board the substantial lesson that we on this side of the Parliament are talking about and that is training for young people and traineeships in relation to youth unemployment. Our attitude is that we believe that if we can improve the offerings for young people in relation to their job and training component we can do something about improving their prospects. We certainly are not in the business of trying to exploit young people.

I say to the Opposition that if it is going to continue to offer contributions to economic debates in this place it should by all means go out and do the research; it should go out and talk to the people. If the Opposition does that seriously it will find that people at the moment are very concerned that it in fact may be sanctioning youth exploitation and not a program to deal with youth unemployment.

In concluding in respect of the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech I say that the economic management of this Government so far has been sound and satisfactory. The Governor-General's Speech is all about a continuation of that sound, economic management. Today I have listed some factors which I believe are important aspects of government management of the economy and society. In the context of this debate I believe it is important to be able to put some positive initiatives before the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Even a cursory look at the tables I have now incorporated shows that primary production has been faced for decades with fluctuating yields, prices and costs. Climate, fires, floods and changing markets, as well as international protection, have always been part of the life of the farming community. Most farmers have learnt to cope with these problems by increased efficiency through better farm techniques, improved plant and animal species, mechanisation and, of course, increased output per labour unit. We may well ask: Why is it so different today? Why is there this level of protest across rural Australia? Why are the world's most efficient farmers, as shown by statistics, taking to the streets with increasing numbers and developing wrath? The reasons are obvious: Government policies at both the State and Federal level over many years have been directed at satisfying insatiable expectations, including those of us in this place, those in the social security system, the public sector, and most employees in the private sector with their security in the work place, indexed salaries and wages, in many cases with absolutely no account taken of their productivity, individual competence, or the capacity of the employer to pay. At the same time the productive sectors, in particular agriculture and mining, have been told by governments to raise production, to improve efficiency and, with the help of the Industries Assistance Commission-usually devoid of any social obligations for its recommendations-to remove any policies that over the years have been aimed at producing for a low priced competitive export market into a highly geared costly domestic environment.

SPEECH.PARA: Can we therefore look for a moment at the paradox of government policy during the past few months. On one hand, there has been the injection of massive funds into government enterprises such as Trans Australia Airlines, the Australian National Line and, of course, support for large employers such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and our car manufacturers. At the same time the Federal Government has encouraged a round of wage lunacy talks by appearing before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and agreeing with wage rises for all. This is no consideration for businesses on the verge of insolvency or any recognition that only increased profitability can lift this nation out of debilitating unemployment and decline into a second rate economy. When will governments, particularly this Government, which is dominated by a very strong left wing, see the link between low costs, low inflation, competitiveness, and a high standard of living? On the other hand, at State and Federal levels, while this has been going on, there have been cost imposts on industries struggling to survive in a desperate thrust to obtain revenue to meet the cost of public sector programs, extravagances and demands. We could well ask whether it is ignorance or simply a wish to sacrifice private endeavour to a socialist state that has resulted in this Government's decisions over recent months. Many of them, unfortunately, have been introduced by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), the very Minister whose support in Cabinet is essential to the well-being of the rural community.

Let us consider just a few of the policies that impose enormous costs on our rural sector, which is struggling to survive. Look at the $60m that this year the Government will take from the grape industry through a wine tax at a time of oversupply and extreme economic conditions. Let us look at the policy that has denied a justifiable domestic price rise to dairy farmers and wheat growers as the Government curries favours with consumers who are generally in salary and wage groups protected against inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party hates the farmers.

—I am pleased to see that so many in the House agree with me! Let us look at the policy that has increased product inspection charges by up to 200 per cent, indexed fuel excises for off-road usage and increased the price of petrol twice this year, despite the fact that it has fallen in United States dollar terms over the past six months. Let us look at the policy which has introduced an assets test that is destroying family businesses and farms that have taken generations to consolidate. Now we see the Government setting out on its final attack on thrift, enterprise and the Australian way of life, an attack that will destroy wealth creation and capital development through capital gains and death taxes.
—And motherhood.

—I would not be surprised, as the honourable member for Charlton says, if the Government does not set out to destroy motherhood as well. I could go on and on, but fortunately the chooks are coming home to roost. I am pleased to see that a number of Government members in this House during this Address-in-Reply debate have now raised concern about the effect of the assets test. I say to the Government that no single issue has caused so much distress to ordinary people, to families who have spent generations pioneering, developing and then consolidating assets from which to produce income for themselves and for the real wealth of this nation. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) may well raise a number of cases of wealthy people receiving a pension, of people who have capitalised their assets. If the Minister were fair, however, he could also raise similar abuses of the same system-instances of people collecting unemployment benefits to which they are not entitled and of single parent benefits being obtained illegally. He could even raise the question of Ministers in this place abusing their rights. We do not penalise everyone for these abuses. Of course, we have to stop fraud and control abuse where it occurs. But we should not penalise hundreds of families and drive them off their land or into poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: For every example the Minister gives, I can supply him with scores of cases which clearly show the destructive nature of the assets test. However, I will give one example of a situation which is repeated over and over again in electorates right across Australia. I cite the case of a third generation farming family comprising a 40-year-old man and wife with four children who own 700 hundred acres which have been valued by the Taxation Office at $300,000. The property is owned jointly by the family and their 77-year-old parents who receive a pension and live in the nearest town in a home purchased by way of a mortgage on the property. This aged couple have now lost the pension, which, of course, throws them back on to the income provided by the property.

What are the options for this family? There is but one, and that is to sell the property. Of course, we must recognise that this is not always possible, particularly at present with the downturn in land prices. But they have to sell the property to provide a secure income for the aged parents, which means that the younger generation must simply move off the farm that has taken three generations to consolidate and seek, if possible, employment elsewhere. This is a criminal act, and if the Government does not act immediately in regard to these serious anomalies it will be responsible for depopulating the rural regions of Australia and destroying the real strength of our economy-the family unit.

I make no apologies for concentrating most of my remarks on the problems of the rural communities. My electorate, which comprises one-fifth of the State of Victoria, socially, culturally and economically ultimately depends on the well-being of agriculture and the businesses which service it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You look after it well, too.

—I am pleased to agree with my colleague. We need only look to the excellent submission produced by the National Farmers Federation and presented to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to see the danger signals and to understand the reason for such rural pessimism. Our terms of trade will fall by 5 per cent in 1984-85. They have fallen by 21 per cent since 1981, while our farm inflation rate has increased by 41 per cent since 1980-81. Already our productivity increases are stretched to the limit and, with lower prices for most commodities, the scope for action rests with reducing farm costs and therefore-I repeat, therefore-with government policies at both State and Federal levels. As the National Farmers Federation pointed out, the Australian farm sector suffers a cost penalty of $16,000 per farmer resulting from protection afforded elsewhere in the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: What, therefore, can the Government do? Of course, it can start by removing a number of imposts. It can remove the excessive tariff protection on imported goods and on many of our manufacturing industries. It can remove excessive spending and borrowing powers by all governments and their authorities. We simply cannot continue to run $10,000m current account deficits and living beyond our means. For the information of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who preceded me in this debate, let me say that the Government could well do something to free up a rigid labour market. In the labour market in Australia it costs 1.9 weeks work to get a week's work done because of regulations, minimum wages, manning scales and penalty rates. The Government could remove some of the over-regulation of our service industries, particularly in the transport sector. Of course, it could radically reduce government taxes and charges.

Sadly, I have the distinct impression that one way or another, as a result of the tax summit and general economic conditions, we will see higher taxes, higher interest rates, higher inflation and less real spending power for our dollar. Taxation, wages without productivity and indirect imposts are the reasons for our decline in world esteem. Governments must act positively by decreasing expenditure and taxation, or it will be not only the farmers and the business sector but also the living standards of the whole nation that will continue to fall.

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Deputy Speaker, May I start by congratulating you and your colleagues elected as Deputy Speakers on your election to that high office. SPEECH.PARA: In speaking in the debate on the Address-in-Reply to the Speech given by the Governor-General on the occasion of the opening of the Parliament, I wish to take a few items from his Speech and make some comments on them. The first and most important issue is the economy of this country. I will quote from the Governor-General's Speech:
The Government's major task in its firm term was the revival of the nation's economy. Economic policy was directed towards the simultaneous reduction of inflation and unemployment.

Inflation and unemployment were certainly the two major problems faced by the Hawke Labor Government on its election. Inflation was running in excess of 11 per cent and no government over the previous 10 years had been able to bring it under control. Today we have the record of this Government already slowing down inflation to 5 per cent and falling further. Real unit labour costs are down to the levels of the late 1960s and early 1970s. We have unemployment and inflation down, the number of jobs is up, and there is strong economic growth.

On the subject of employment, I quote from the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 14 March to a combined meeting in Canberra of the Economics Society and the Industrial Relations Society. When speaking about employment growth, he stated:

Employment growth had been extraordinarily strong through 1983-84 but, as measured in the ABS survey, weakened earlier this financial year. Since then, there has been a return to strong growth in employment. One hundred and ten thousand jobs have now been created in the first eight months of this financial year. The Jeremiahs seized with glee the weaker figures early in the financial year as indicating that the Budget forecasts were wildly over-optimistic. With the latest figures from the Statistician, employment has already expanded by almost 2 per cent in the first 8 months of the year, and the Budget forecast of about 2 1/2 per cent now seems well within our range.

The latest labour force figures bring total employment growth in the 22 months since we changed the course of Australian economic history at the National Economic Summit Conference to 360,000. We are running ahead of our target of half a million new jobs in our first three years of office.

The dramatic contrast between the experience of employment growth under the Labor Government, and that under the conservative government which we replaced, is a measure of the relative success of the two Governments' approaches to economic policy.
In less than two years under our policies, 360,000 new jobs have been created. In seven years and four months, a total of 340,000 new jobs were created under the policies of our predecessors.

The figures speak for themselves. However, while we laud these figures, we recognise that there are serious problems among young adults and young people in relation to employment opportunities in this country. We still need to do much more in that area. However, long term unemployment has eased significantly. The number of people unemployed for nine months or more fell by 43,000 or 17.5 per cent over the year to January 1985. There are still 202,300 people who have been out of work for at least nine months. That is still far too many.

Teenagers have also shared in the labour market improvements. The unemployment rate among teenagers looking for full time employment is now 23.1 per cent, a fall of 4 percentage points since March 1983, and five percentage points since the high point in July 1983. They are still very high figures and a lot of work needs to be done. The number of unemployed teenagers looking for their first full time job has fallen by 22,000, or 28 per cent, since the high point in December 1983. Over the last year to February 1985, teenage full time employment has risen by 16,600, or 3.8 per cent. Unemployment amongst the 15- to 19 year-olds looking for full time work has dropped by 21,800, or 12 per cent. We are now well on the track to meeting our employment targets. These are a direct contrast to the figures that were being presented by the previous Administration in this country.

In assessing the approach of the two governments, I refer to Hansard and the speech given on 21 March by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), the Leader of the National Party of Australia, when he was talking in the Address-in-Reply debate. He said:
As far as the Address-in-Reply is concerned, at this stage I wish to outline something of the climate back in 1983.
Then he went ahead with a litany of excuses. The first excuse was this:
Honourable members will remember that we had been through an extraordinarily difficult time internationally.
The problems were nothing to do with that Government; it was all international. A little further on he said:
Then we ran into one of the worst droughts in Australia's history.
The drought became the Government's excuse at that time. Further on he said:
Honourable members will recall that we then had the wages explosion, which bore heavily on every employer.
Their own so-called decentralised, deregulated policies created that enormous wage explosion that did such terrible harm to the economy in the way it was carried out. Further down again he states:
Of course, we then decided that it was essential that in some way we contain that wage explosion. We introduced the wage pause . . .

They were lurching from one remedy to another. They had no idea of the direction in which they were going as far as the economy was concerned. It is quite clear that the approach of this Government is having a much more beneficial effect for the country. I refer again to the speech by the Governor-General, and quote a little further down:
The Prices and Incomes Accord has played a crucial role in Australia's economic success.

The Opposition at times has criticised the prices and incomes accord, but any thinking person in Australia fully understands just what that has meant as far as Australia is concerned. The Prime Minister has returned only tonight from a trip to Canada, where he was invited by the Canadian Government to address their summit on how things were being done in Australia and to give them an outline of what has occurred here. I quote from the speech the Prime Minister gave in Canada on 23 March to the Canadian Government on the accord. He said:
The Accord embodies a commitment to wage restraint within a centralised wage fixation system--
something that our predecessors could not manage at all--
that is built on well-established features of the Australian industrial relations reality.

The Accord with the trade union movement is part of a wider compact between the Government the Australian community embodying commitment to consultation and consensus, to the equitably distribution of the benefits of economic growth, and to the achievement of sustained, strong non-inflationary growth.
These three commitments are inter-related parts of the one program.
No progress can be made on any one of the three without support from the others.
All relevant parts of society will support the national effort only if two critical conditions are met: that the benefits of growth are distributed equitably--
all people must share in it--
and that the process of growth, and the links between growth and the realisation of the goals of all groups in the community, are widely understood.
There can be no beginning without the basic framework of policies on employment, participation, taxation and expenditure which promote confidence in the equitable distribution of growth in incomes.
He went on to say further:

But the process of consultation also plays a valuable role in informing the Government on community values and preferences, on the detailed effects of proposed policies, and on alternative and sometimes superior means of attaining Government objectives. The Government proposes a major review of the Australian tax system during 1985. The Government has given the people of Australia explicit commitments regarding the budget deficit, budget expenditures and taxation. None of these will be increased as a proportion of gross domestic product in 1985-86 and over the Government's second term.
We need to look at that trilogy to see just what the Government has said about that. Once again I refer to what the Prime Minister said in this regard in his speech on 14 March 1985:
Further reductions in the deficit in money terms in 1985-86 and as a proportion of GDP over the life of the current Parliament;
No increase in Commonwealth tax revenue as a proportion of GDP in 1985-86 and over the life of the Parliament; and
A reduction in Government expenditure as a proportion of GDP in 1985-86 and over the life of the Parliament.

These are the clear aims of the Government in the present circumstances. I believe that while the economy is on the track it is on we have every opportunity of achieving that. The Government will move further towards its objectives of removing unnecessary controls in the financial system and increasing the efficiency of the financial and business sectors. The successful applicants for new banking authorities will be announced shortly.

Let us see what other policy areas there are in which the Opposition could possibly lay some claim to credibility. We have talked about its economic policies which were a shambles. That is the first priority that honourable members need to look at. What had been the case in this country for so long-it was the reason the assets test had to be introduced-was that people were not declaring that income from that property and were expecting the Department of Social Security, or the Australian Taxation Office through Social Security, to help to pay the rent of another member of the family. The point honourable members opposite miss is that involved in the case which was cited today by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher)-he talked about a dairy farm-this factor: Two young people, perhaps of the same age, and in direct competition with each other, could be running two properties. One person may be paying a genuine rent to run his business and the other could have his rent paid by Social Security. That is not fair for the person who is competing with him in the industry and it is not fair on the taxpayers.

Let us get to the point. Let us refer to the genuine members of the public; the ones about whom we are really concerned. They are easy to name. They are the people who have always declared their incomes from any rents they have ever received. They have small blocks around this country-many of them soldier settlement blocks. They have their 40, 50 or 60 acres, or whatever, that was cut up after the Second World War. Those blocks are too small to be farming units as is, but they rent those blocks out to someone next door or someone up the road. Those blocks have a value in the dairy industry at least. They have a value in other industries, such as wheat and wool. Those people receive an income of around $60 a week for renting out 40 acres of land to a next-door neighbour. Those people have declared that income. In the past they received a top-up pension which brought them up to the standard rate on which most pensioners are living. It is not a high amount.

Where we have the distortion in the system at present is that valuations have got out of kilter because of hobby farmers moving to those areas. Some of those hobby farm valuations are way and above what the land will produce. The valuations have created a situation where some of those people have lost their part pensions. The Minister has informed us that we are on the right track; we can fine tune the situations where those people have a genuine case. We can put it to the Minister and the Department that those people have never cheated the system; they are honest Australians; they have declared the income. I have not heard any member on the other side of the House say that. In every speech I have heard they have always lamented about the person who has never declared the income received from rent. A person is expected to be able to give the farm away to a son, a son-in-law or a daughter and let him or her use it for nothing while the Department of Social Security pays the rest. It is totally unfair either way-on the taxpayer and on those people in the industries who are having to compete against those people to whom I referred.

We are quite clear in our position as far as the assets test is concerned. We understand when the people are honest. We are not bringing in a system that intends to crack down on anybody who has been doing the right thing. I can assure those people that this Government, as it has shown by its compassion in its distribution of income, will continue to show compassion for the genuine, honest person who has a problem with the assets test.

The Government has no Ministry for small business despite the general recognition throughout the world today of the economic contribution that the small business sector makes. Ministerial responsibility for small business in Australia is tucked away in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. That is the order of importance-industry, technology and commerce. I would like to touch on a few statistics in respect of small business. It has been recently stated in the United States of America that since 1978 Fortune's top 500 companies shed one and a half million of their work force. Yet, in that same period, small business created six and a half million jobs. If that is not a message to a government that continues to ignore the small business sector, I do not know what is. Eighty-five per cent of the jobs created in America by business in recent times have been created by businesses that are less than five years old. In the 1978-82 period large businesses in Australia lost or shed 288,000 jobs; small business created 310,000 jobs. Still the Government chooses to ignore and neglect this sector.

What about the recent strike by public servants which was brought about by the ineptitude of the Government and its refusal to accept the realities of some of the legislation brought in by previous Governments? I compare that to a factory worker paying $5 a day for the privilege of going through the factory gate for a boss who might not have the financial ability to pay him at the end of the week. That is the way it should be done. We will bring down private members' legislation to deregulate. We are not going to have another committee about that. I am fed up with government by inquiry, and so is the community. We are going to do things. We believe on this side of the House that judgment exists. It was displayed in the last election campaign that the front runner could not cop it. But the back runner showed the great ability of a good stayer. He stuck in there, in the running, where things were tough and he improved all the way. We know all about front runners in the racing industry. SPEECH.PARA: The first Hawke Labor Government seriously addressed the problems of the unemployed and those on community welfare benefits. This is a continuing task but one on which we in government will not turn our back. There is still very much to do. Thankfully, gone are the days when the ill and the infirm were treated like third class citizens when they applied for an invalid pension. Now they do not need to feel like street beggars, unwanted and uncared for. We have a government that is responsive to their problems.

In the period available to me I would like to address some specific matters of great concern to Australia's standing as a nation in today's world. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has recently in this House condemned the outrageous killing of black people in South Africa on 21 March this year. Similar killings at Sharpeville were carried out by the South African Government 25 years to the day before these recent killings. The Minister, speaking on behalf of this Labor Government, reaffirmed the Government's total opposition to the injustice and inhumanity of apartheid. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), wholeheartedly endorsed this Government's statement. I applaud the shadow Minister for his stand. I hope he can hold that line.

We respond when such an outrage as the recent South African killings is given world-wide publicity, but support for the black people of South Africa is needed on a continuing and increasing basis. The conditions of the South African blacks are without parallel in today's world. Let me give some facts to help illustrate the evil of South African apartheid. In South Africa last year 114 men were hanged. I repeat: 114 men were hanged. That is 24 more than in 1983 and 15 more than in 1982. All 114 were men, of whom 87 were black, 24 were coloured, two were white and one was of Asian origin. Just as evil and terrifying is the number of deaths behind bars. In 1984, 126 people died in police custody due, according to official reports, to injuries before arrests, 21; suicide, 38; natural causes, 61; assault by other prisoners, 6; and detainees taken to hospital, 15. The Minister for Foreign Affairs was correct when he said:

The Government believes that the vile and repugnant apartheid system remains the basic cause of the unrest and discontent amongst South Africa's majority black population. Twenty three million blacks, 77 per cent of the population, cannot be deliberately excluded from the political life of their country.

I am pleased to advise this House of the fine work being carried out in Australia by such organisations as the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation. The driving force is Jim and Irene Gale, two wonderfully dedicated people. There is also the work of Eddie Funde, the representative of the African National Congress. I try to assist as a trustee of the African Liberation Trust Fund. I commend the Minister for Foreign Affairs on his statement. I congratulate the Opposition shadow Minister for his support. I would be delighted to see more of my colleagues support the Campaign Against Racial Exploitation and the African Liberation Trust Fund.

The people of New Zealand have shown an amount of courage, almost unequalled, in their stand against South African apartheid. In a land where rugby is a national sport it speaks volumes that the New Zealand people stood up against the South African rugby tour of 1981. Again, one of our oldest and closest allies, New Zealand, has shown that special kind of courage. I refer of course to its determination to struggle to secure a nuclear-free environment. The people of New Zealand in a general election on 4 July 1984 voted for a Labor Government and a policy of no nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships to enter their ports. The people of New Zealand are to be congratulated on their decision and their determination. In today's mad nuclear arms race, we must surely hope and pray that their lead will be successful and that it will be followed by many other nations.
In the Governor-General's Speech at the opening of this Thirty-fourth Parliament, in outlining our Government's position the Governor-General said:
The Government remains deeply committed to advancing the cause of peace, arms control and disarmament.
He went on to say:
. . . will actively promote programs for the International Year of Peace in 1986, and will advance the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone proposal.

The stand taken by the people and the Government of New Zealand can and will greatly assist our Government in pursuing and, indeed, achieving a South Pacific nuclear-free zone. Indeed, the South Pacific Forum held in Tuvalu in August 1984 adopted Australia's set of principles to establish a nuclear-free zone. It should also be stressed that the South Pacific Forum accepted unanimously that individual Forum countries were free to make their own decisions about visits of United States nuclear-armed or nuclear-powered ships. That principle was as follows:

That South Pacific countries retain their unqualified sovereign rights to decide for themselves, consistent with their support for these objectives, their security arrangements, and such questions as the access to their ports and airfields by vessels and aircraft of other countries.

The concern for things nuclear is world wide. Tens of thousands of concerned anti-nuclear demonstrators recently took to the streets in Belgium protesting at the proposed siting of cruise and Pershing II missiles; likewise in the Netherlands.

Canada, America's closest ally, does not permit the stationing of nuclear weapons on Canadian soil. What is more, it does not consider that such a policy is incompatible with its obligations to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. United States nuclear weapons were removed from Canada at the request of the Canadian Government in the late 1950s. The Canadian Government's official policy was most clearly expressed by the Minister of External Affairs, Mr Clark, in the House of Commons on 15 February 1985. The Minister made the following observations:

The position of the Government of Canada on the question of nuclear arms on Canadian soil is abundantly clear. We do not allow nuclear arms to be stationed on Canadian soil. In the event of any contingency plan which might call for the stationing of nuclear arms here, this Government retains its right to refuse nuclear arms on Canadian soil, and this Government would be prepared to exercise our option to refuse nuclear arms on Canadian soil if we believed that to be in the interests of Canada.

It is my view that those who would criticise New Zealand for its stand are out of touch. They are batting on the wrong side. The concern around the globe about things nuclear is growing. New Zealand has taken a courageous, forward-thinking stand and I sincerely hope that the Australian Labor Party Government will give New Zealand every possible help and support. We can demonstrate such support at the South Pacific Forum to be held in August 1985 in the Cook Islands, where the Forum countries are to discuss a nuclear free zone in the region. Support for the principled stand taken by New Zealand will be echoed in many countries around the globe. Even the United States has nuclear free zones covering 80 communities and nearly 10 million people. In Japan more and more people are concerned over possible visits by United States nuclear-armed ships. Declarations of local nuclear weapons free zones by Japanese towns and townships more than doubled between 1982 and 1984, from 64 to 146, and included at least five of Japan's 47 prefectures. It is accepted there will be nearly 300 such declarations by the end of 1985. No, New Zealand is not out of step.

The New Zealand position has been determined by the belief that the nuclear arms race is the single greatest threat to international security and that the nuclear powers have no right to involve every other country in the risks of nuclear confrontation. This position was spelt out by Prime Minister Lange in his opening speech in the foreign affairs debate of 9 October 1984 when he said:

Many believe the nuclear arms race to be the greatest single threat to their security. The Government commits itself to do all it can to reduce that threat. In the end realism dictates that nuclear powers will begin to exercise the responsibility they have to all of us when they are prepared to consider two basic propositions. The first is that the security provided by their competition to build more and improved weapons is illusory, and the second is that their security and ours can be enhanced only through agreement to slash the nuclear arsenals . . . The nuclear States have absolutely no mandate for imposing the risks of nuclear confrontation on all other countries and holding the world at ransom.

The trilogy, if it can be achieved, will simply cement a further record deficit in place for the next three years and will increase the cost of servicing the public debt. Servicing of the Commonwealth debt at $5.6 billion for 1984-85 stands as the fifth highest item of government expenditure contained in the Budget and represents a continuing tax on future generations of taxpayers to pay for this and past generations' extravagances. This represents over 8 per cent of Commonwealth expenditure. Just bear in mind that the debt is rolled over and is not taken into account as a repayment in those figures. What a record! Yet the economy is paraded as the high achievement of the first Hawke Government. Obviously many more comparisons could be made, but the conclusion we must draw from these few is certainly not that of a strong, fair and equitable Australian society.

The manner of redressing all these factors lies not within the province or capacity of the Labor Government or the socialist Government, as it has proved to be. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) listened to the last speaker on his side, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott). Does the Minister fully agree with everything the honourable member was saying? If nothing else I believe that speech highlights the many factions there are within the Labor Government today. Not only are there those factions within the Party but there are its union commitments and all the other pressure points. In this the Labor Government has shown itself to be a government divided, with neither the will nor the capacity to redress these problems that confront Australia.

I want to mention these instances, quite apart from the one I have just mentioned: The President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Cliff Dolan, prior to the last election insisted on a further tax on capital property and wealth, and mentioned that that would be part of the new economic and industrial deal that the unions would do with the Government. The ACTU therefore has staked its position as the non-elected government of Australia. The socialist Left does not want to mine and use our available resources, such as uranium, and is intent on destroying the ANZUS alliance along with all the other treaties and agreements with the West. The comments by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) over the many long months since the election, and those by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) indicate that the situation as far as they see it is that the ANZUS alliance is no longer necessary, that we can do without our American allies.

Also, the powerful Caucus Resources and Trade Committee is committed to more and not less protection. The rigidity of the central wage fixing system is putting more persons out of work in the private and productive sector at the same time when the government or public sector is employing more in unproductive areas. The Government's pre-Budget leaks indicate a commitment to more and not less expenditure and also major checks on means testings of parents' income in regard to the receipt of unemployment benefits, the slashing of spouse rebates and also a national superannuation scheme. All of these are matters which have been leaked to the Australian public and we wait with bated breath to see what happens.

One must admit that not all of these problems can be blamed on the present Government. But in spite of the many positives, such as the breaking of the drought and the revival of the world economies, the Government of the Thirty-third Parliament proved to be quite incapable of coping with the situation that eventuated in its term. The first Hawke Labor Government showed this by the breaking of 120-odd 1983 election promises, in spite of the positives that I have just outlined. The former Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, has said it all in so many ways. It has been said that Australians have become so accustomed to the hand-out mentality that we lack direction and purpose. Be that as it may, governments have certainly raised an expectation in people that they have only to ask and it will be granted. Australians should have been presented with loftier ideals within the Address-in-Reply than the Address has suggested. For instance, in the words of my colleague the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), who is in the chamber, maybe we should pause and ask ourselves: Where are we? Where are we going? What do we want for a greater Australia? That would in itself have formed a first-class address to the nation.

Let us look at the taxation situation and analyse events throughout the world and the economic performance of other nations. The general argument in the tax debate-I refer to the coming summit, for instance-is that on the one hand some say, and I believe this to be the situation, that lower taxes should stimulate higher output by increasing incentives to save, to invest, to work hard, to innovate. A more moralistic approach can then be taken for the collection of a just and fair tax as opposed to the more common attitude of today, to avoid and evade a higher, unfair and unjust taxation regime. On the other hand, others will argue that lower taxation will benefit the rich at the expense of the poor; that funds for social services available from tax revenues will diminish and widen the gap between those who have and those who have not; and that there is no real redistribution of wealth in a lower taxation system.

I have found some very interesting calculations which have been carried out by the World Bank staff and which have been presented in its working paper No. 605. They provide some empirical evidence on the links between taxes and economic growth. In the report, 20 nations, spanning almost the entire spectrum of world incomes, were compared in pairs, in duos, within the same per capita income basis. SPEECH.PARA: Let us now look at examples that we can recognise within the Pacific rim and compare them with Australia's high taxing performance. For instance, Korea's average per capita income for 1979 was between $US1,400 and $US1,700; Singapore's average per capita income was $US3,800 to $US5,950; and the figure for Japan was $US8,800 to $US11,950. While there are other differences quite apart from the taxing structures, such as industrial and productivity differences, Australia must recognise that all three of these Pacific rim countries are out-producing, out-manufacturing and out-trading Australia in almost every department. It is important to recognise these facts because we are told so often that Australia's future depends on our trade in what will be the great economic zone of the world in the future. In that zone we will be competing with Canada, South Africa, the United States and South America, which have the same advantages with regard to freight as we do.

For instance, when I was in Japan in 1978, Australia had a favourable balance of trade with Japan of three to one. Today in 1985 it has equalised. I am sure that those who know the 'flat rate' regime of Hong Kong would realise that it too is out-performing Australia. I do not count the differences in costs-that is, labour-as a standard of comparison because I believe that costs are a result of high taxation, low productivity and the misuse of industrial muscle. Under the combination of all three of those factors, Australian costs are on the ceiling when compared with those of any of the other countries within that rim that I have just mentioned.

Let us look next at Australia's industrial and wage fixing system. Industry in Australia cannot claim to be free enterprise when 50 per cent of the costs to industry are the most regulated and rigid of all the cost components. Labour is certainly not a free resource. The Australian work force is approximately 55 per cent to 60 per cent unionised and wages are centralised on the industrial or arbitration commissions. In the United States, about 20 per cent of the work force is unionised and this works because of contracts and collective bargaining between the work force and management. Our major trading partners provide at best two weeks annual leave, as against our minimum of four weeks. With a 17 1/2 per cent loading, Australians are paid more to take their holidays than they are to work. Penalty rates in the United States commence after an employee works his 40 hours in one week. In Australia they are paid after seven hours' work a day. An employer is expected to pay unskilled youth labour at adult skilled labour prices. Likewise, university graduates, with all the theory and no practical application, make the same demands on industry when entering their first jobs. In addition to these conditions, if the arbitration commission's decision is unfavourable, the worker withdraws his labour and his wife and family are eligible for income support from the state-that is, the taxpayer.

The unemployment benefit in the US is met from contributions of employees and employers. To this should be added the additional costs for no additional productivity of the other claims that I mentioned earlier which are made and granted to get around the prices and incomes accord. Yet, on top of this, unions will be seeking productivity bonuses this year. One might well ask: What productivity has there been? If such bonuses are given, where will they lead? Large businesses might be able to pass on the cost, but small businesses will have to retract their business activity and will have to cut down their work force. That is basically what will happen in regard to productivity claims. One has only to consider the national loss in the power dispute earlier this year in Queensland and the Commonwealth Public Service strike to wonder where Australia is heading. A writer in the Bulletin only the week before last made this very pertinent observation:

Once upon a time, when there was no Arbitration Commission, no basic wage or 38 hour week, no sick or holiday pay, no unions or awards, it was necessary for workers to strike to get a fair deal. It was the only way to put their case.

In 1985, when we have basic awards and conditions for workers and an Arbitration Commission to hear any claims or grievances, the right to strike is no longer necessary. It is uncivilised and outmoded. It has degenerated into a standover tactic which is slowly destroying the living standards of all Australians.

The writer was Mrs Lorraine Prins of Nebo in Queensland. That is the crux of the whole matter. The living standards of all Australians are being destroyed. That living standard today is overvalued and can only suffer devaluation in the future if Australia continues down the same path. The vicious circle continues. We protect our local industries, not so that they can trade externally, but just so that they can sell internally against the challenge of imports.

Our loss of productivity provides for more and more regulations and control. In order to survive in business today in Australia a person will have to be strong enough to overcome many regulations and controls. He will have to overcome controls governing the labour market, overproduction, subsidies to the competition, the monopolisation of the marketing of these products. He will have to pay the share of protection afforded his competitors and to less efficient industries. There will be controls over the valuation of his money. Monopolies will be set up in banking, transport and communications. The business will become the unpaid collector of taxes on behalf of government. There will be payment of taxes on payroll, indirect taxes, royalties, rental resources taxes and others. That person will have to maintain standards for the environment, health, building, staff, factory, machinery and pay the fees to ensure those standards are met. There will be controls over the hours the business can trade, with special fines and penalties for non-compliance. Finally, if a profit at the end of this is achieved it will be taxed at 46c in the dollar before one cent is available to finance inflating stock, repay the loans, provide the debtors, replace the machinery or pay the dividends.

The Labor Government now intends to tax that person on yearly wealth or capital gain if the business is sold. If it all becomes just too much and death results, there is the likelihood of a death duty. Little wonder that, when compared with the freer and less regulated United States economy, Australian business finds difficulty in competing with the United States or any other Pacific rim countries. That business person is not paying for productivity and efficiency, he is paying for inefficiencies. The National Farmers Federation estimates that each farm in Australia pays $16,000 yearly for the inefficiencies of other industries and protection. Each Australian produced motor car costs $3,000 to $4,000 more to the Australian consumer. I understand that each worker in the motor vehicle industry is subsidised by about $23,000 a year. One's mind boggles as to what further subsidies we pay as Australians to the regulated monopolies through our postage stamps, telephone calls, air fares, electricity charges, railway freights and so on.
