SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak this evening in response to the Governor-General's Speech delivered at the opening of the Thirty-fourth Parliament just over four weeks ago. Many of the matters raised in that Speech could well do with further elucidation so that the record of this Labor Government is further illustrated for the benefit of honourable members. Might I at this stage, however, congratulate all of those new members who came into this place at the beginning of the Thirty-fourth Parliament on their election to the Parliament and on the manner in which they delivered their maiden speeches. Despite our philosophical differences-the differences that will exist between each of those new members-I believe all those honourable members have come here with one major overriding thought and theme, that is, to do their best for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well to remember the situation in Australia prior to March 1983 and what has happened since Labor came to office at that time. It is hard to believe that just two years ago the Australian economy was in recession and the loss of jobs each year was running at 200,000. When the Labor Government came to office the inflation rate was running at 11.5 per cent and the gross domestic product, or growth rate, was crawling along at minus 2 per cent with a forthcoming deficit of $9.6 million. That was the state of the economy which confronted this Government just two years ago.

Most of the matters that were raised by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), have not occurred just over those previous two years. Indeed, most of the problems besetting this nation were in existence prior to those two years. A lot of the blame for those shortcomings must be sheeted home to the former Government. Hard decisions were needed at that time so that the downward slide into economic chaos would be arrested and new policies put in place so that the economy could start the slow upward movement towards recovery. This Labor Government took those hard decisions and set into place new policies and new initiatives which have brought about the fastest and most dramatic economic recovery of any country in the world.

In that first term of office the Government sought and received the support and co-operation of the trade union movement and the Australian people in embarking on a course never before attempted during peacetime. This was a course of national reconciliation, recovery and reconstruction. The success of receiving that support and co-operation was achieved through the forging of the historic prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the process of discussion and consensus at the National Economic Summit Conference attended by business and community leaders.

We tend to accept far too blandly that our economic recovery occurred just as night follows day, without any assistance from the Government. We must not forget that this Labor Government was able to achieve the remarkable economic recovery we have in Australia today. That is something no conservative government has been able to do. The people of Australia need to be reminded time and time again that any return to conservative government in Australia would turn back the economic recovery clock to pre-1983.

When one listens to the speeches of honourable members opposite in this debate it is easy to realise just how short their memories are. This is particularly so when we heard what the new conservative members had to say in their maiden speeches. They talked of the policies that the Liberal Party had for achieving economic recovery, for taxation equity, for industry revitalisation and for providing jobs for so many people presently unemployed. Those new members have learned nothing from the past because it was the party to which they belong and which they now represent that brought economic ruin and despair to the people of Australia during the period from 1975 to 1983 when their party was in government. Theirs is a party whose policies were proved unworkable, yet, they have the hide and audacity to criticise the policies of the present Government which have achieved the economic miracle we have today. If nothing else, I appeal to those new members opposite to learn from the mistakes of history.

I have no doubt that every honourable member of this House desires a continuation of economic recovery and full employment, but this is not possible without a realisation that past policies enunciated by the Opposition parties have not and will not work. We need the co-operation of Opposition members in sustaining our nation's economic recovery-not confrontation. We need their help, and not their hindrance. For the sake of our fellow Australians let us all work together in promoting recovery and building a better future for our citizens.

I now come to some of the other matters which I believe need some mention and which have been referred to in the Governor-General's Speech. Housing has always been referred to as the great Australian dream. Not only do Australians want a roof over their heads but most of them ultimately want to own their own home. For those unable to achieve home ownership welfare housing through the States' housing authorities forms a large and important sector of the housing industry. Housing is a very good barometer of the nation's economy because the housing industry is usually the first to suffer in a recession.

Before outlining the Government's achievements in respect of the housing industry, let me quote from two articles which appeared in daily papers one year apart. The first article appeared in the Australian on 10 August 1982 and was headed 'New home approvals down 32 per cent'. It stated:
Approvals for new homes were at their lowest in eight years during June, leaving 1981-82 as one of the bleakest years on record for the housing sector.
The influence of record interest rates and falling economic activity reduced the number of new dwellings approved by 18,000 to 138,504 during 1981-82-32 per cent since last June.

According to the Housing Industry Association, the slump will last through this year, costing about $1250 million in investment and the loss of about 40,000 jobs in the building and related industries.
Bureau of Statistics figures issued yesterday show there were 9255 new private sector homes approved in June-3.4 per cent lower than May.
The figures indicate the Federal Government's latest housing package, announced in March, has done little to halt the flow of funds away from home lending.
Disastrous
This has had disastrous effects on building activity.
The national executive director of the Housing Industry Association, Mr Bill Kirkby Jones, said the recession inflation and high interest rates had brought about the situation.

''Frequent increases in housing interest rates, the prospect of further increases, and marked uncertainty about security of employment have combined to seriously erode the confidence of potential buyers,'' he said.

The association, a major party to the March housing agreement, has put before the Government a seven-point submission aimed at improving the flow of home finance without the need for higher interest rates.

Mr Kirkby Jones said research by the association had shown that higher interest rates, designed to improve the lending capacity of banks and building societies, would only push the industry deeper into recession.
The second article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald dated 20 September 1983 and is headed 'Housing Emerges from Slump'. It reads:
It is now official-the housing industry has emerged from recession.
A spokesman for the Housing Industry Association, Dr Ron Silberberg, said there was now ''no question'' that the home building sector had come out of the recession ''and it has come out very fast''.
Dr Silberberg said a recent HIA estimate of 122,000 commencements this financial year (in 1982-83 commencements slumped to a 20 year low of 105,000) could now prove ''a little conservative''.

He was commenting on Bureau of Statistics figures for the June quarter, which showed that in seasonally adjusted terms, home building commencements had reached their highest level since the first three months of 1982.

Yesterday's figures showed that seasonally adjusted private sector commencements increased by 8 per cent to 19,600 between the March and June quarters. The actual number of commencements increased from 16,500 to 19,800.

Other statistics from the bureau brought good news for individual home buyers. The price index of house building materials continued to record very moderate increases, with a rise of only 0.4 per cent in July.
In the 12 months to July, the index increased by only 6.7 per cent, significantly below the latest annual Consumer Price Index inflation rate figure of 11 per cent.

The significant increase in housing in those 12 months was brought about by the increase in confidence of potential home buyers following the election of a Labor Government in March 1983. It was a firm indication of consumer confidence which had come about before the commencement of the Government's first home owners scheme which did not come into operation until 1 October 1983.

Government incentives and consumer confidence have resulted in 135,000 homes being commenced in 1983-84 and the estimate of 145,000 in the current financial year is well on target. The January 1985 commencements of almost 14,000 represent an increase of 12 per cent over January 1984, and the 12 months housing commencements to January this year are up 18 per cent over the same period to January 1984. The first home owners scheme has been a great success in enabling first home buyers to achieve the great Australian dream of owning their own home. Since the scheme began over $321m has been paid to 106,000 households, and by the end of this financial year approximately 142,000 households will have benefited from the scheme. In less than 18 months this Government has provided more in direct assistance to first home buyers than the previous Government did during its whole tenure of office.

I turn briefly to the Government's involvement in the provision of public housing in conjunction with the States. The new housing agreement, providing a record $1,580m in Federal and State funds for public housing in this financial year, was a firm indication that the Government had every intention of continuing to provide an increased amount of money towards the provision of accommodation to those unable to provide for their own housing needs. Under the agreement the Commonwealth provides funds to the States for public rental housing and home ownership assistance. The Federal contribution of $623m to the agreement this financial year is 60 per cent higher than funds provided in the last year of the Fraser Government. A minimum $510m will be provided by the Commonwealth to the States for each of the next two financial years, a marked improvement on the $200m base level funding provided under the 1981 agreement of the previous Government.

The agreement contains specific programs for rental housing assistance to pensioners and Aboriginals. The special problems of youth have also been addressed in that all States must now accept applications for public housing from youth. The new crisis accommodation program includes special provision for capital funds to be directed to youth refuges. Special allocations in the agreement for 1984-85 include $52m for rental housing for Aboriginals; $35m for pensioner rental housing; $27m over three years for a new local government and community housing program to enable local government and community groups to provide innovative low cost rental housing-for example, hostels and boarding houses; $13m for a new short term crisis accommodation program covering accommodation for youth and women's refuges; $22m for mortgage and rent relief to home buyers and renters experiencing short term financial difficulty. The new agreement reaffirms this Government's commitment to ensuring that all Australians have access to adequate and affordable housing. It also provides for a new system of low start loans administered by the States with repayments geared to income. Applicants will be able to combine this assistance with benefits under the Government's first home owners scheme. This will enable a family earning as little as $175 a week to repay a loan of up to $40,000 in just over 20 years without permitting more than 25 per cent of income in repayments. Eligibility will be determined on the basis of need.

The most rewarding aspect of the Labor Government's initiatives in getting the economy working again, including the stimulus to the housing sector, has been the increases achieved in the creation of additional employment opportunities. Soon after achieving office the Government set about creating 500,000 new jobs in its first three years of office in accordance with its election promise. At that time of course many considered such a promise to be an impossible task incapable of achievement. Opposition members particularly have been the most vocal critics of the Government's proposals in this regard. Their remarks have done nothing to engender business confidence or to induce business to expand operations to create new job opportunities.

The achievement of the 500,000 new jobs target is well in hand as to date 360,000 new jobs have been created since May 1983. This financial year alone to the end of February 110,000 new jobs have created. In February itself employment rose by 45,200, the third highest monthly increase on record. Just as important of course is the fact that this increase in employment has been associated with a significant fall in the level of unemployment from 10 per cent to 8.3 per cent. In the area of youth unemployment there has been a fall of four percentage points. This is very good news for young people. As the House will be aware, there has been a long term decline in employment prospects for young people from the mid-1960s to the early 1980s, during which period the number of full time jobs for young people declined considerably. This occurred in an almost constant wave for teenage girls and in two bursts for teenage boys. Fortunately, because of the Government's policies, this trend appears to be reversing, and in the last 12 months growth in full time employment for teenagers has increased by 3.8 per cent with the creation of 16,500 new jobs. We have had a decline of 22,000 in the unemployment figures for those teenagers seeking full time work, a reduction of 12 per cent. The teenage unemployment rate, as I mentioned earlier, has declined by 4 per centage points from 27 per cent to 23 per cent.

We do not, however, intend to let the matter rest there. We realise that special action needs to be taken to ensure that a greater number of job opportunities are created for the youth of our nation. On the basis of recommendations received from the independent Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs, chaired by Mr Peter Kirby, the Government intends reforming labour market programs to give greater emphasis to improved training and work skills development. Particular emphasis will be given to providing broad skill-based training as one way to improve the opportunities open to young people, especially for those who have been unemployed for a long time. In recent months discussions have been undertaken with State governments and with education authorities so that the recommendations can be further progressed as a matter of urgency. The community employment program, which was launched in August 1983 and had created 57,000 jobs by the end of 1984, will also be responsible for assisting a further 65,000 people during the current financial year.

I shall now speak briefly about industry development. Australia is involved in an ever-changing world. We are dependent upon trade for our prosperity and, as a result, in order to remain competitive we must adapt to changes in the world and its markets. Industry in Australia should be as responsive as primary production is to world change. The policies from the 1950s to the 1980s have been to make industry inward looking and essentially reliant on a small and fragmented market. As well, past policies have resulted in a dependence, at least in the psychological sense, on government support and industry laziness in addressing issues such as management and marketing skills, product quality and design, research and development, and technology transfers. This is not an argument for the removal of protective banners for Australian industry. Rather, what I am saying is that protection can no longer be looked upon as a saviour for industry as it has become too burdensome on the Australian community. In any case, protective measures are largely offset by movements in the exchange rates.

Australian industry needs a more deliberately export-based policy and much greater investment in research and development and modern plant. Our existing export industries are under pressure as our traditional export markets are diversifying to rival sources. Thus the creation of a competitive manufacturing sector to pick up additional exports, or at least to be more competitive, must be a major objective of the Government. Means other than the tariffs can be used in restructuring Australian industry. There are more systematic ways of restructuring sections of industries. The Government's car and steel industry plans are good examples of this more positive approach to industry restructuring. The Opposition has often stated that to achieve effective restructuring Australia would need to have a wage structure competitive with that of other countries and that Australian wages are too high. However, a country such as Sweden, which has a higher wage structure than ours, is a great exporting nation simply because its products are advanced and highly innovative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise the issue of jobs, supposedly the principal concern of the National Economic Summit Conference and supposedly also, from reading the Governor-General's Speech, a prime continuing concern of the Government. My speech on the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech contains the message that nothing in the Government's legislative program nor any element of its political platform effectively tackles the root causes of unemployment. But it goes beyond that. It asserts that the cumulative errors of 80 years of history must be looked in the eye and the power structures of our society altered before we can return once again to a period of full employment. This is a lesson for all parties and all groups, as most Australians, individually and collectively, have held to the view that the centralised systems of conciliation and arbitration, both Federal and State, have on balance had a beneficial effect on wages and conditions, industrial harmony and employment. At some times and under certain conditions this belief may have been justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not propose to argue that question because it is irrelevant to our present and to our future. What I argue now is that the system has become little more than an instrument of the application of excessive union power, a power that is exercised not only to the detriment of the unemployed and those outside organised labour but also to the detriment of organised labour itself through a denial of the benefits of rapid economic growth. Enough analysis of the causes of unemployment has been done for us now to know why it occurs and if we removed the blinkers of established practice, to devise a plan to reduce it to nominal levels.

I will deal now with the causes of unemployment and then go on to suggest a plan of action. Technological change has been cast as a villain in the riddle of unemployment. It is true that the introduction of technology leads to the loss of jobs in particular places or industries. New technology requires adjustment. However, we must be careful not to blame the new technology for our failure to adjust. We should concentrate instead on those rigidities in our economic and social structures that inhibit adjustment. If we do not, the extraordinary advantages of making new technology our servant will pass us by and be used by others to our disadvantage. If coach builders had successfully resisted the advance of Henry Ford, just think what the consequences for economic growth and employment would have been.

We are all agreed that one major ingredient of an increase in employment is faster economic growth. Quite apart from the vagaries of international markets and the variable effects of the weather on our rural industries, there are many internal rigidities in our economy, rigidities defended by powerful interests, that make our economy less open and less competitive than it should be and therefore restricted to slower growth rates than are possible. These rigidities include the constraints on the capital market identified in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System; the problems of manufacturing industry identified in the report of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies to Manufacturing Industry and in the report of the Crawford Commission to Advise on Assistance to Industry, and in successive Industries Assistance Commission reports; the shortcomings of our educational system, identified in the report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment; the limiting effects of public sector activity through uncompetitive trading enterprises, particularly in transport and communications; inefficient operating activities, for example, in the delivery of services such as health; and excessive regulation of enterprise.

However, the rigidity that most affects the level of unemployment, affecting not only the rate of economic growth but also the efficiency with which the available work is shared out, is the rigidity of the labour market. It is this rigidity that was the cause of the Government's advisers at the Economic Summit having to say that Scenario C, although more favourable in employment prospects than A or B, could not be followed because it was 'industrially unrealistic'.

There are two main aspects of this rigidity in the labour market that prevent people getting jobs. The first is the general level of the price of labour, and average weekly earnings are one guide to that level. The second aspect relates to the wage that must be paid and the rules that must be followed before someone can employ someone else. These rules are the complex body of laws and industrial awards that must be observed by prospective employers if they are not to break the law. Taking the first aspect, the general level of wages and salaries-the price of labour-it follows in logic that as the price moves up the pool of money available, from whatever source, to employ people will employ fewer people than if they were all paid slightly less. This fact at least was recognised at the Summit, although the logical conclusion drawn by the late Sir Keith Campbell that any increase in the general level of wages at that time would reduce employment prospects was not accepted. It was 'industrially unrealistic'. In other words, it was not acceptable to the unions who have, under present conditions, the industrial might to enforce their views on the rest of the community regardless of the public interest. Of course, I am not saying that we can never have wage increases. I am merely pointing out the uncomfortable fact that if the average level of wages is pushed up too fast ahead of gains and productivity, fewer people will be employed. The available money will be spread over fewer higher cost units.

The second aspect, the wage rates for individuals and the rules for employing people, has been built up over time to protect the gains in conditions that Australian workers have secured over the years. I suggest that these rates and rules have now become so complicated and so stifling that while they might in the short term protect the conditions of those in employment, they are having the effect of removing altogether that security in an increasing number of cases by the loss of jobs. Worse still, they are preventing potential employers from taking people on in the first place. They are also preventing entrepreneurs from even bothering to start businesses in what could be the next growth areas in our economy.

Many of the rules governing employment in Australia were originally designed to protect the interests of workers in a society long since gone, a society of single income families-mum at home and able to shop during the day, dad at work for five days a week, sport on Saturday and religious observance on Sunday. This is a world far removed from the pluralistic society we live in today in which the role of women has changed dramatically. Increasing numbers of people want to exercise their free choice, to buy or to sell, to work or not to work as suits their own particular wishes. It is not surprising that when we try to impose these working patterns of a bygone age on our modern society and therefore try to make people do things they do not want to do, we restrict consumer choice, reduce employment prospects and slow economic growth. The needs of the industries of today and tomorrow are far removed from those of the 1930s and 1940s; yet the rules for employment still bear the old stamp. We cannot expect the bullet train to run on the old permanent way.

Everyone knows what these restrictions are. There are restrictions on trading hours and manufacturing hours. There are penalty rates applying to weekend work. There are various loadings for holidays, shift work and literally hundreds of other reasons. There are required ratios of senior to junior employees. There are restrictions on the employment of casuals. There are increasingly costly retrenchment provisions that have the unintended effect of discriminating against the least employable. All these requirements were seen as benefits by unions and by employees at the time they were gained. Some industries can afford them. However, under our industrial system all industries and all employers are obliged to provide them whether they can afford them or not. Conversely, prospective employees who do not demand them are obliged by the law to remain unemployed despite the potential availability of a mutually beneficial contract-beneficial not only to the parties directly involved but also to the consumer in the form of additional service or lower prices.

It is often said by observers of the labour market that it is so distorted that market forces do not apply, that the laws of supply and demand are inoperative. It is true that there are massive distortions there, but that does not mean that market forces do not exert themselves. They certainly do apply to the relationship between the price of labour and the supply of jobs. For example, we cannot force a potential employer to pay a price for someone's labour when he thinks the price is too high. The unemployment benefit for an untrained, inexperienced youth of 15 years is $50 a week. An employer might well employ the youth at double the dole rate-that is, up to $100 a week-but he is much less likely to take him on at the award rate of $150 a week. The young, the inexperienced, the partially disabled and the elderly who could be employed at a price and under conditions of service that would be mutually acceptable to employer and employee alike, subject to basic safeguards enacted by law, are currently excluded from employment because the law requires that they be paid more than their economic worth or enjoy conditions that are impossible to achieve within the requirements of a viable, profitable business.

How many thousands of small businesses are there where the expansion of the business is prevented by the inability of the proprietors, often husband and wife and family, to go beyond the use of their own unregulated labour? If, as we are told, small enterprises are the greatest potential employers of new labour, creators of new jobs, surely these restrictions are preventing the creation of tens of thousands of jobs in small business. The fact is that proprietors of small business are subsidising the regulated areas of the economy by providing their own labour at rates well below award levels. If they did not, the economy would not work and those enjoying award wages and conditions would be paying a great deal more for the services that they currently enjoy.

Electricity workers in Queensland should hide in shame when they take advantage of the lower prices or convenient services offered by the hard working proprietors of these small businesses. What we are talking about is sharing the work out, not by introducing yet another set of complicated rules superimposed on the existing maze, but by removing rules that prevent the market from sharing the work out through millions of independent mutually beneficial transactions. Magically this process of flexible sharing will have the additional effect of releasing new creative energies that will add to the sum total of work available to be shared. In short, it will promote economic growth.

There is the challenge to our political system and to our society. The trade union movement will fight to preserve the existing rigidities, but opposition will not stop there. Some employer groups rely on the flow of inflationary wage settlements to prevent competition from other employers not immediately subject to the resultant awards. All sorts of established interests are involved. However, if we cannot as a society face up to this question of the price of labour and rules for employment, we will be excluding a significant proportion of our people from the economic mainstream and the essential human dignity and self-respect that come from employment. We simply must face up to it. Nothing will happen unless we have a clear objective of such obvious common sense that community consensus can be built around it-not the shoddy consensus of the vested interests of the past but a consensus of growth and hope, an agreed vision of the future.

Our objective must be a labour market in which, firstly, each individual can be rewarded according to his or her individual experience, talents and performance; secondly, managers are able to tailor remuneration packages and work patterns to the competitive needs of the enterprise; thirdly, particular industries and enterprises have the flexibility to meet changes in domestic or global conditions; fourthly, average labour costs are more responsive to changes in economic fortunes, an essential requirement for the successful management of the Australian economy; and fifthly, employees and employers alike are protected by law against unfair practices or breaches of contract. Our objective is thus a flexible, decentralised labour market, individual freedom and a greater sense of personal worth to individuals, giving managers the capacity to perform in a competitive world, but also imposing on managers a duty to solve at the work place problems which many of them have abdicated to employer organisations and to industrial commissions.

Can this objective be achieved without a wage cost breakout, massive industrial disruption or damage to our social fabric? I believe it can. The main obstacle to change is the widespread belief that the system cannot be changed. Once we believe it can be changed, we can plan rationally how to do it. I am certain that a dramatic new factor is about to enter the equation, that is, the conversion of one side of Australian politics to the belief that the system can be changed. It is not surprising when we think about it that the system has resisted change so successfully. Not only have we had all the powerful unions bullying everyone, including their own members should they question this way of doing things; the Labor Party, the political arm of the trade union movement, supporting the system with legislation and political clout; Federal and State commissions vigorously defending their continued existence and jealously protecting their influence; industrial lawyers guarding their briefs; and industrial relations experts in major enterprises and employer groups, while continuously protesting, nonetheless supporting the system; but we have also had successful coalition governments accepting the system as the basis of labour market regulation in Australia.

This is about to change and I predict that that change will be of historical significance to this country, releasing the energies of its citizens by lifting from them a dead weight of restrictive practices and denials of human freedom that in their hearts they know are at once ludicrous and dangerous. I am confident that with one side of politics converted to a completely new set of objectives-objectives that can, because of their innate common sense, swiftly capture the public's imagination-the balance of argument will gradually but surely change as it has in the financial area. The defenders of entrenched privilege will go on the defensive, relying more and more on naked force to maintain their position.

There will need to be an examination of a wide range of measures to weaken the existing power structures, avoiding head-on clashes with the most entrenched groups initially; encouraging more freedom in the less regulated, more likely unionised areas, such as small business; and gradually removing the props from the more highly protected areas. The particular measures to be considered might include: A public education program pointing out the absurdities of the existing system and the benefits of the proposed system; removal of the privileged legal status of unions; opting out provisions for bypassing Federal and State commissions; repeal of legislation or regulations that prop up restrictive labour practices, such as the coastal shipping legislation; reduction of protection behind which rigid labour markets can be maintained; privatisation of government operations into competitive units-for example, in Telecom Australia installation work; the maximum use of contractors for government work; and the cessation of union dues collection by employers. There will also need to be a protection for individuals not wishing to join unions for whatever reason. With clear objectives, a consistent strategy, continuing public education and, above all, the determination to succeed we can bring about the changes that will halt the slide of Australia towards third rate economic status and we can restore full employment.

Opposition politicians, certain sectors of the media and certain so-called pensioners' representatives have resorted to just about everything in their campaign against the assets test-even to the point of suggesting that a type of social security Gestapo will be created to body-search pensioners and ransack their homes to make sure they are not hiding any valuable assets.

But we never seemed to have time to talk about where Australia was going; about the falling standard of living of the ordinary Australian; about how we could give them a good and secure future; about how we could encourage new industries in Australia; and how we could get rid of the dead hand of government, our Government, that was stifling initiative and taxing us into oblivion.
Indeed, these great deregulators, these champions of free enterprise failed. The honourable member for Menzies is also reported as saying:
We actively and wrongly opposed the breaking up of the Telecom . . . did little to encourage deregulation or competition in the finance industry---

The previous Government is condemned by a person who was within its own ranks. The truth is that we have a mixed economy and it is necessary for any government to find a balance between providing services and cutting fat and stimulating enterprise. Conservative governments failed for 30 out of 35 years. It is a difficult task but finally we have a Government that is prepared to take it on. Indeed, I feel very hopeful that the next three years will see this Government continue in that direction to a greater extent.

I would like to speak about two things very briefly which perhaps are the most pressing domestic problems that face us. The first is, of course, unemployment and in this respect one must again look at the Opposition rhetoric. The Opposition shadow spokesman says: 'We will clear away the myths and get to the reality'. Members of the Opposition talk about deregulating youth wages. They talk about the terrible public sector and about how all growth has been occurring in that sector. But how in practical terms do they think they are going to solve this problem? There is no substance in what they have said. They tell us to wait and see what their policy will be. The reality is, of course, that there was a massive wage push associated with the destruction of centralised wage fixation by the Fraser Government. This was the catalyst for the recession that we have experienced.

The reality was that unemployment under the Fraser Government was at a level of 10.3 per cent. It is now at 8.3 per cent. The reality was that under the Fraser Government jobs were being lost at the rate of 250,000 a year. Since this Government has come to office 360,000 new jobs have been created. In addition, there has been a drop of 5 per cent in youth unemployment since the July 1983 figure was released. Indeed, the annual growth in the private sector has been increasing.

Finally, let me say something very briefly about what we might see as a necessary evil in our society, and that is taxation. If we want to demand services we must all consider the level of taxation. Again, the free enterprise people, the deregulators and the free marketeers, could not even deliver tax indexation. For over 30 years the system lost its progressiveness. Over time it has destroyed incentive. The only incentive that exists is that to avoid paying taxation. Indeed, honourable members opposite did their very best to assist those who wanted to do this. At the end of this year nearly two and a half million Australians will be paying tax at the marginal rate of 46 cents in the dollar. Not only are taxes higher but also they are unfair and the burden is falling on the middle and low income earners. The aim of this Government is to restore progressiveness to the taxation system, to release the burden on low and middle income earners and perhaps to renew the incentive to produce rather than directing effort to avoidance. It is a difficult task and many sectional interests will have something to say. They will lobby very heavily. The political opportunists will snipe at us. But it is too important for us to do badly. The right tax package is perhaps the most fundamental thing to our continued growth and development.

Overseas travellers will find that air fares and tours will cost perhaps 20 per cent more. Mortgage interest rates, already at historical highs in real terms, will rise for many families and small businesses in Deakin. The price of everything we purchase from overseas, last financial year totalling $24 billion, will rise sharply, affecting our cost of living index and putting inflationary pressure on the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Our inflation rate, still much higher than that of our trading partners, our current account deficit and the rigidity of our work rules, all coupled with the instability of this Government, have eroded confidence in our future. On behalf of the families of Deakin, I appeal to this Government to get its economic policies in order. We must get our inflation down, get our international trading in balance, and break the job protection cartel. To be supporting national wage rises, public severance pay rises, and so-called productivity pay rises just when a huge slice has been taken from our national wealth can lead only to further loss of confidence in our economy. The Government now has to prove to the international community and to the families of Deakin that it is not asleep at the wheel-and those families will be watching and judging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pensioners of Australia today are covered by a very much fairer pension system because of the introduction of the assets test. I would like to spend some time tonight having a look at a bit of the history of the assets test. It is clear from the examples of some of the speeches of honourable members opposite that people on the other side really do not know what they are talking about. The history of our pension system goes back to good old Bob Menzies, the pariah of the Liberal Party of Australia, who gave the people of Australia the freedom of choice to look after their own retirement incomes. The freedom of choice principle still operates today. I hear it talked about now and again on the other side of the House. Certainly, we can have a look at the protection system which Mr Menzies built into that system. He had an income test and he also had an assets test. In actual fact an assets test was a feature of the pension system in Australia between 1908 and 1976. So for a relatively short time in our history we have not had an assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government had the guts to put one back in because we could see what was happening to the pension system without one. People of substantial means, as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) pointed out the other day, were able to arrange their affairs in such a way that they were able to get a pension and the fringe benefits. What they really did was to lower the amount of money we could give to pensioners in need. So when we talk about the assets test we should remember that it is not a new thing. It has been in existence for quite a while.

Let us look at the demise of the assets test. I would ask those students of politics to look at the relevant dates because they will notice that proposals in relation to the pension always appear just before a Federal election. The tapered means test which was introduced in September 1969 affected 47,000 pensioners. In September 1972 there was an increase in the free area and 30,000 pensioners were affected. Also in September 1972 we had the superannuation and annuity concessions. That was, again, as I have said, just before the Federal election of that year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did not save them.

—It did not save the Liberals that time and neither did a subsequent proposal. In November 1976 there was the introduction of the income test and 200,000 pensioners were allowed to have pensions when the assets test was scrubbed. If we thought it all ended there we were wrong. In November 1982, in the infamous family Budget of that year, 420,000 pensioners were affected by the increase in the free area. That was another sop to the pensioners to try to get back into power. But, as history records, that did not happen and the Hawke Government came to power.

SPEECH.PARA: There are only two options the Liberal Party or the conservatives can put to the people of Australia if they are really dinkum about scrubbing the assets test. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) knows that well because at least he has a grasp of the fundamentals behind the scheme. Next time the Liberal Party can either raise taxes to give the pension to those people who are scrubbed off this time-the richest 2 per cent, I remind honourable members-or it can do as it did before. This is the likely option: It can allow the value of the pension to drop over time. History shows that when the Whitlam Government was kicked out-

TALK.START.PARA: —Kicked out? I thought the people made their decision.

—Sacked, or whatever one likes to call it. When the Whitlam Government left office the pension stood at 24 per cent of average weekly earnings. When the Liberal Party was kicked out of office in 1983 the value had shrunk by about three percentage points. We can see what the Liberal Party is all about. It is all about the erosion of the pension system by stealth.

SPEECH.PARA: We can look at some of the supporters of the assets test that was re-introduced by the first Hawke Government. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) the other night bagged the assets test. But what did he say before he was a candidate for the Liberal Party? This is what he said:
The government is absolutely right in introducing an assets test . . .
He went on to say:
The latest version of the assets test proposed by the government offers a much more equitable formula than has previously been produced . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—This is the honourable member for Mayo who bagged the assets test the other night. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be folly . . . to reject the assets test outright, as it is the only avenue which leads to effective control over the spiralling costs of retirement policies.

He would be a good Liberal because he, like the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), is saying that it is equitable, but when the Liberals get into power they change their tune. John Elliott, the Treasurer of the Liberal Party in Victoria, said:
I have always argued that the social security system should be based on need. Therefore I do support the assets test . . .

The Liberals support it too. We can look at what we will do in the next election campaign. The pensioners of this country will always remember the party that lied to them and the party that put in the scare tactics. If the Liberals were responsible they would be agreeing with us and educating the pensioners, as did the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar) who did not get them upset. At least he had the guts to tell the bloody truth which is something the Liberals never did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not get involved in the debate about the pensioners of Australia, but the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) missed the most important point. A lot of politicians miss it too. We are all different and pensioners are all different. Some work a lot harder than others and some do not work at all. Some who have had their pensions chopped are looking at other pensioners living on the street corner who have wasted their money all their lives. That is the reason why there is a little bitterness and why the politics of honourable members opposite will not win out in the end on that point. We are all different and honourable members remember that. But I do not want to get involved in that debate tonight. I will leave the discussion of the elderly until a little later in the year.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing has been worrying me. My two younger colleagues the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles)-they are exceptionally good colleagues-need to be aware of what is happening in Tasmania. I do not want to attack the Wilderness Society continually and I know there are some very good conservationists on the other side who get very upset when I attack the conservationists. Honourable members must be aware of what the conservationists are trying to do once again in Tasmania. Last week I looked at a big professor from the University of Tasmania. He looked straight into my eyes; I was standing on a box. I said to him: 'Why do you get so upset about the dam issue?' He said to me: 'It really was not about the dam, Bruce. It was a cause'. Tears started to fill his eyes and I started to realise that another cause was occurring in Tasmania. The Wilderness Society is now trying to tamper with our wonderful forestry industry which employs 4,000 Tasmanians. It is very important to the economy. The wets and the dries of the Liberal Party of Australia and the Left, the Right, the Centre and all the other conglomerations on the other side of the House had better be aware that the conservationists want to destroy the timber industry of Tasmania. They want to preserve the rain forests in Queensland. They will do it in a manipulative way. They will walk around the forests. They will go to the media and entice some of the media to support them. This will be very, very serious for the economy of Tasmania.

My two colleagues had better be aware of this fact. They had better not be trapped like some of our good colleagues were over the dam issue. They were trapped by false impressions of what was going to happen in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a lot of good advice.

—It is very good advice and I hope to goodness that many others listen to it. The conservationists are working in Tasmania. They are starting to condemn the wood chip industry. It is very important for the economy. They are starting to tamper with the park in the south-west at the moment. They are trying to increase its size. They are trying to do exactly the same as they did with the dam issue. We know what happened then. They conned a lot from the people who worked against the people of Tasmania. That is the reason why the people of Tasmania elect five Liberal representatives. They know dash well that they were conned. But this time I hope my two colleagues will fight the conservationists very hard and make certain that they are not led up a track-
—No worries.

—I know that they will. I am sorry to give advice. I am the older member now and I can give advice. I know that some of my bright colleagues on the front bench do not take any notice of me, but many people do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, 21 March was Afghan International Day. It was also the beginning of the Afghan New Year and the first day of spring in Afghanistan. Since the Soviet invasion 21 March has assumed an additional significance as it is celebrated as Afghan International Day all around the world and amongst the millions of Afghan refugees in Pakistan and Iran. In December 1979 the Soviet Union sent thousands of its troops into neighbouring Afghanistan to prop up the unpopular regime of Babrak Karmal. Since then the Soviet troops have been used to maintain Karmal in power in Kabul. My Party, the Australian Labor Party, and the Australian Government are opposed to the Soviet invasion. I am opposed to the invasion of Afghanistan. Such action by a big power to impose its will on a small neighbour is to be condemned by all those who esteem and support the right of self-determination of all people, small and big.

SPEECH.PARA: I view the Soviet action in Afghanistan with the same disgust as I view the United States military intervention in Central America and I condemn both with the same vehemence. I hope that honourable members opposite will join me in condemning the US action, the long string of US military interventions in Central America, just as they are willing to join me in condemning the Soviet invasion in Afghanistan. In the last five years the Soviet army has fought many battles against the mujahideen and it is no closer to achieving complete control over Afghanistan than it was five years ago. The people of Afghanistan do not and will not accept foreign rule. They are a free people and are fighting for their independence. The British learnt to their detriment that the freedom loving people of that mountainous region overlooking the crossroads of Asia will not accept foreign rule.

In 1981 I visited Pakistan and had the opportunity to see the Khyber Pass. I stood right on the Afghan border looking down into Afghanistan. I felt that the ancient tradition of love of freedom and independence of those mountain tribes that inhabit that rugged but magnificent country will not be easily subdued, even by modern arms of a foreign power. At the same time while visiting the area I came into contact with the refugee problem and the enormous suffering caused by years of fighting. At that stage, in 1981, there were by the most conservative estimates more than a million Afghan refugees in Pakistan alone. I have seen the camps, the tents and the mud huts, and while there was no starvation amongst the refugees, thanks to the generosity of international relief agencies, life in the camps was miserable. The Afghan refugees escaped the fighting and the dogmatic influence of a foreign power only to come under the influence of Pakistani Islamic fundamentalists. What a choice, and what a choice of dictators, to live under Zia or Karmal! However, since I was there the situation has worsened and the number of refugees is now put as high as four million.

Thousands of civilians died as a result of fighting and many more thousands were injured. Many people have lost their crops and livestock and there are widespread food shortages. The world should be made aware of the suffering and the misery of the Afghan people. Our Government has provided generously in the past to relieve the plight of the Afghan refugees. However, there is still more need for humanitarian aid. At the same time we have to work towards the achievement of a negotiated peaceful solution. Unless the fighting is stopped, unless the millions of refugees are resettled into their homeland, the instability of the region will continue. What is even worse, the suffering of the Afghan people will go on, the suffering which can be prevented by peaceful negotiations, while war and continuous fighting will not resolve anything. Therefore, I hope that our Government will do everything it can to bring about peace in that region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise a matter relating to the standard of living of every Australian and particularly relating to the future of many of our provincial cities and towns. Of course, I refer to the farm sector and the contribution it makes to that standard of living, earning as it does still well over 40c of every export dollar and therefore contributing very directly to the well-being of every Australian. On Tuesday, 5 March last, a farm cost summit was held in Canberra between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), a number of senior Ministers and a series of representatives from the National Farmers Federation as the peak organisation representing most rural organisations across Australia. At the conclusion of a four-hour session the only concrete thing to come out of the farm cost summit was simply the creation of yet another committee to do what? Just to investigate the accuracy of some of the statistics contained in the submission of the National Farmers Federation to the Federal Government. I have to say that that news, when released as a consequence of and following on from the summit, was a bitter disappointment and a bitter pill right across rural Australia because there had been quiet hopes that for once the message was getting through, that for once there might be some positive action in respect of the farm cost situation and the very serious plight of many primary products on the world markets at present.

SPEECH.PARA: The farm sector is not crying wolf this time around. There are some who think it is typical of the farm sector to cry wolf the moment there is the possibility of a drought or a flood, that there are always good times and bad times, that those things are cyclical and that the farm sector will bounce back. This time around two notable differences are causing the farm sector to suffer very seriously indeed. Firstly, a previous mechanism which allowed increases in productivity to occur in many commodities and so enabled farmers to withstand cost increases has evaporated. The productivity cow has been milked dry. There is just no room to manoeuvre in extracting yet further increases in productivity in so many commodities produced by Australia's great rural industries. Secondly, the cost increases have become incessant. They have far exceeded the consumer price index and so many of them relate to government charges, State and Federal, of one sort or another. This time around the farm sector has very real and genuine problems. It does not cry for subsidy for subsidy's sake. The years of doing that are long past, and that is where they should be-in the past. What we want and what we seek are realistic accurate policies from government, State and Federal; a realistic appreciation of the costs associated with the farm sector; more economic efficiency in terms of the weaponry utilised by government in managing the economy-for example, the replacement of the tariff that costs some $14m a year on the import of autoheaders into this country by a bounty which would merely cost some $2m and protect the Australian jobs that are at stake in relation to that issue.

What the farm sector wants is for its message to be heard loud and clear between now and the meeting of the committee that will look at the statistics. It hopes that when the farm cost summit mark II version occurs some time in April there will be not just another committee to consider matters but real and positive action because the rice industry, the dried fruits industry, the dairy industry and a number of other industries that I could mention are in serious trouble and in need of specific, direct reasonable action and-I mention it again-not just subsidy, indeed not even subsidy, but policies which will help provide for a lessening of the cost-price squeeze which is so affecting the farm sector.

I add, in conclusion, that the assets test and its hardship provisions, which are well known to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), have done little to ease the mind of many in the farm sector and many retirees because of the stringent guidelines associated with the administration of those hardship provisions. That has been an added burden on the farm sector and one which has done nothing for the confidence of the sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to place on record my wholehearted welcome of the statement made earlier today in this place by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) that by September our Government will be in a position to select a second Sydney airport site. It is of very great interest to, I think, all Australians that the environmental impact statement will be published some time next month, that for the following eight to 10 weeks public comment will be called for and that a decision will finally be made in September of this year. It is a matter of great relief to not only the 75,000 constituents in my electorate but also the 1.1 million people in Sydney that a second Sydney airport is coming. It is with a great deal of satisfaction that I welcome this, because it is a great victory for grass roots community action which united people of all political persuasions, all sorts of business persuasions, right across the southern Sydney area and the inner western suburbs, to stop a second runway being built into the bay. It was a great victory because we had right on our side at all times.

SPEECH.PARA: If any members of this House, especially those opposite who were prepared to sell out my electorate at the drop of a hat when they were in government, should doubt this, let them have a good look at the cost figures and the capacity figures for the potentially expanded Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport as opposed to a second airport and also the inevitability that such a second airport should come about, let alone the ecological disaster that would have left Botany Bay to the sand crabs. It is interesting that at this time, with the bicentenary coming up and the importance of Botany Bay to the history of this country, we are seeing the death of Botany Bay and the slow environmental choking of it. I say unequivocally to this House tonight that, if a second runway had been built into the bay at Mascot, we could have written off forever the bay and all the life contained in it.

This has been a very difficult decision for this Government to make; but it has not shied away from the task. The former Minister for Aviation, the present Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), did an excellent job at the beginning of this undertaking and has been followed equally well by the present Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation. He has done an excellent job, unlike the honourable members opposite who showed cowardice on this issue when they were in government. The Government has taken the bit between its teeth. Honourable members opposite, when they were in government, simply saw this issue as a political one; that is all. They were prepared to write off the Federal electorate of Barton after the 1980 election when they won the seat by a small handful of votes. They knew that in 1983 the electorate of Barton could not be held by the Liberal Party. Having lost all other seats around it, they were prepared to put politics ahead of what was right for the industry and what was right for the inhabitants of Sydney and the commercial and business interests of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you deregulate the industry?

—It is all right if one owns Moonie Oil; but there are many poorer people in business in Sydney. The second Sydney airport, therefore, was an issue that this Government took on principle, and it has fought it through and won. It is now an acclaimed position throughout Australia, in industry and otherwise, that a second Sydney airport is a necessity. If there is a need for further proof of the cowardice of the Liberal Party on this issue, I refer to Malcolm Fraser's letter to Premier Wran, of April 1981, when he conceded that a second Sydney airport had to built anyway. The question remains today: Why did the Liberals filibuster for so long? Why did they try to sell out my electorate?

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I say that the present position arrived at by this Government will represent the best of both worlds for my electorate and the areas of Sydney around it. We will be saved from the future social, economic and health costs and environmental disasters that another runway in the bay would present. At the same time we are saved from incurring any job losses because not one job will be lost at Mascot with the operation of a dual airport system. Indeed, those people in mobile positions in the work force-especially professional people from my electorate-will be presented with dual job opportunities with yet another airport as a potential employer. This decision has been a brave one, a well thought through one and one which historically will stand this Government in good stead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of us know how those living in the biblical era regarded tax collectors. Time certainly has not changed public opinion and it is not difficult to understand why, when some of the decisions made by the Commissioner of Taxation are considered. I wish this evening to raise the matter of the interpretation of the definition of 'aids to manufacture'. A company in my electorate engaged in the housing and construction industry has purchased a computer which is used, not primarily and principally, but exclusively, in the design of non-standard roofing trusses for the building industry. The machine, on the basis of information input, will plot and draw and also compile cutting lists which are all essential to the manufacture of the said trusses. The program used was bought from another country which also provides the basic intermediate materials used in the manufacturing of these trusses.

SPEECH.PARA: 'Aids to manufacture' means goods for use by a registered person in the course of carrying on a business, being machinery, implements and apparatus for use exclusively or primarily and principally-in this company's case-firstly, in testing or checking the quality or specifications of goods processed in any process or treatment for the purpose of bringing goods in to the form or condition in which they are to be used for the manufacture of the goods or, secondly, in carrying out scientific research in relation to manufacturing operations conducted by the manufacturer. This latter condition may seem inappropriate. However, although 'scientific research' is not defined, an indication of its scope is illustrated by the following examples of equipment that have been accepted as being for use in scientific research: The investigation of possible improvements to his existing factory processes for the production of certain products and the investigation of processes of manufacturing of certain products which he contemplated manufacturing. These were accepted by the Commissioner.

It seems to me that, if the first example, which covers the testing and checking of goods processed, and not the design thereof, is not sufficient for exemption, surely 'scientific research' as it has been interpreted provides reasonable grounds for the Commissioner to agree that this particular computer is an aid to manufacture. It is not used for anything else. The age of technology, wherein manufacturers have an opportunity to use modern equipment-indeed, they are virtually forced to do so to remain competitive and capable of meeting job requirements-ought also to generate enlightened thinking and an appreciation by the Commissioner that the description given by one of his officers in rejecting this company's claim-that under the Act an aid to manufacture is something used directly in manufacture and not an item used in design-is a Dark Ages type of thinking and fails to comprehend the requirements and the demands of modern business.

I urge the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to direct his officers to approach this area of aids to manufacture in a more realistic manner. The narrow interpretation that the Commissioner has put on 'aids in manufacture' is affecting many areas of business throughout this nation. I believe that the interpretation should be updated to take into consideration the fact that Australia has moved into a technological era and therefore aids to manufacture are not just those welding machines that are used to manufacture motor vehicles, but that certainly modern technological equipment items, such as computers, also should be considered as an aid to manufacture, particularly when they can do the computations of a technical nature which are so necessary for this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the few moments that are left in this debate to raise an issue that is important to me and, I believe, to every other member of parliament-that is, the difficulty that people throughout this nation have in filling out government forms at the national, State and local authority levels. I make an appeal to Ministers and Government departments to think very carefully about the forms that they produce because they are creating trauma. We saw this in recent-
—In the assets test.

—I accept the point. Some of the requirements placed on people to fill out forms are unnecessary. It is certainly true that when it comes to making application for all types of jobs and pensions people are unnecessarily faced with great difficulty. In this time and age, when insurance companies are able to consider simple English policies and it is something that is happening right across the board, government ought to consider as well that we have various levels of education. But it is not always the level of education that is the problem; it is simply the difficulties in understanding the terminology. I have seen this in recent times when people have been filling out sponsorship forms-
—It sounds like Mick's affidavit.

—I know that the honourable member for Bennelong has great difficulty in understanding his party's policy, let alone forms and applications. I suggest that this is a serious matter. I would have thought that, if members of the Liberal Party had had any sensitivity to the need of people, they would have supported this proposition instead of trying to make fun of the whole issue. I suggest that, if they bothered to spend some time in their electorates, they would support the issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 25 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many air services are presently provided per week between Japan and Australia under the Japan-Australia Air Agreement.
(2) How many of these services are presently operated by (a) Qantas and (b) Japan Airlines, and between which airports do these services operate.

(3) Is there provision for additional services to be run between Australia and Japan; if so, from which airports within Australia will these services be operated, by which carrier and when could they commence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Six regular air services are operated each week between Australia and Japan under the Australia-Japan Air agreement.
(2) (a) Qantas operates three B747 combi services weekly between Australia and Japan
(b) Japan Airlines currently operate three weekly B747 services between Tokyo and Sydney.

(3) Under new arrangements formalised by the Japanese and Australian Governments in Tokyo in September last year, Qantas and Japan Airlines may each operate up to four B747 services weekly between Japan and Australia from April 1985. In addition it was agreed that a once weekly B747 joint freighter service could be introduced from 1 October 1985.
Qantas' additional service will operate Sydney-Brisbane-Tokyo. The company's Perth service which currently operates through Sydney-Brisbane will then operate Perth-Sydney-Tokyo.
Japan Airlines' additional service will operate between Tokyo and Sydney.
The joint freighter service will also operate between Tokyo and Sydney.
